G.  Duty of City Administrator. The city administrator shall inform any party applying therefor of the number or numbers belonging or embraced within such lot or property as provided herein. If the city administrator has any doubt as to the proper number to be assigned, he/she shall determine the number of such lot or building. 
H.  Newly Constructed Buildings. Whenever any house, building or structure shall be hereafter erected or located in the city, in order to preserve the continuity and uniformity of numbers of the houses, buildings and structures, the owner or his/her agent shall procure the correct number or numbers as designated by the city administrator for the property and shall immediately fasten such number or numbers so assigned upon the building as provided herein. No building permit shall be issued for any house, building or structure until the owner has procured from the city administrator the official number of the premises. 
I.  Penalty. If the owner of any building required to be numbered by this section shall neglect for 60 days to attach and maintain the proper number on such building, the city administrator shall serve notice requiring such owner or occupant to properly number the same within ten days. If the owner or occupant does not attach the number within ten days, he/she shall be in violation of this section and subject to a penalty as provided in Chapter 1.24. 
(Prior Code, § 6-2-12; Code 1998, § 12.04.110) 
Sec. 12.04.120. - Obstruction of public ditches. 
    No person shall in any manner obstruct or cause to be obstructed the free passage of water in any public gutter, ditch, culvert, swale or drain or place or cause to be placed any rubbish, dirt, sand, gravel or any other matter or thing so that the same is likely to be carried by the elements into any public gutter, ditch, culvert, swale or drain. 
(Prior Code, § 6-2-13; Code 1998, § 12.04.120) 
Sec. 12.04.130. - Use and/or lease of city equipment. 
    The city shall not permit any person to use and/or lease any city equipment for private purposes. 
(Prior Code, § 6-2-14; Code 1998, § 12.04.130) 
Sec. 12.04.140. - Dirt and debris on streets. 
A.  In the interests of public safety, health and general welfare, community appearance, and efficiency of operation, it is unlawful to place, throw, leave, in any way deposit or permit to be deposited, or permit to remain any dirt, leaves, rubbish, litter, debris or material of any kind upon any street, sidewalk, alley, drainageway, or public ground in the city. 
B.  The owner, occupant or person in charge of private premises, which places, causes or permits to remain, any such materials upon any street, sidewalk, alley, drainageway or public ground in the city shall immediately remove the materials at no cost to the city. 
C.  1. The operator of any motor vehicle which tracks, drops or places any materials upon any street, sidewalk, alley, drainageway or public ground in the city shall immediately stop and remove the materials at no cost to the city. 
2.  In the event the operator is performing work under the control or authority of the owner, occupant or person in charge of the work on private premises, and the operator causes the deposition of any materials upon any street, sidewalk, alley, drainageway or public ground in the city, and the operator fails to remove the materials as required in this Subsection C, the owner, occupant or person in charge of the work on the private premises, shall remove the materials at no cost to the city. 
D.  In the event the materials are not removed from the street in accordance with Subsection B or C of this section, the city shall cause the removal of such materials and shall charge the operator, or the owner, occupant or person in charge of the work the cost of the removal. In the event the person charged for the removal fails to pay such costs within 30 days, it shall be entered on the tax roll as a special tax against the property. 
E.  In addition to the costs of removal, the operator, or the owner, occupant or person in charge of the property shall be subject to a penalty per occurrence as prescribed in Chapter 1.24. Each day that the materials are not removed, shall constitute a separate offense under this section. 
(Prior Code, § 6-2-15; Code 1998, § 12.04.140) 
State Law reference- Littering, Wis. Stats. § 287.81. 
Sec. 12.04.150. - Damages to streets and public property. 
A.  In the interests of public safety, health, general welfare, community appearance, and efficiency of operation, it is unlawful in any way to cause damage, injury or destruction to any portion or any fixture of any street, sidewalk, alley, drainageway or public ground in the city. 
B.  The person which causes damage, injury or destruction of any portion of any street, sidewalk, alley, drainageway or public ground in the city shall immediately stop and notify the police department that he/she has caused such damages and shall correct the damages within ten days at no cost to the city. 
C.  1. In the event the operator of any motor vehicle or equipment which causes damage, injury or destruction of any portion of any street, sidewalk, alley, drainageway or public ground in the city, fails to report such damage, it shall be considered a violation of this section. 
2.  In the event the operator is performing work under the control or authority of the owner, occupant or person in charge of the work on private premises, and the operator causes the damage of any portion or fixture of any street, sidewalk, alley, drainageway or public ground in the city, and the operator fails to correct the damages as required in this Subsection C, the owner, occupant or person in charge of the work on the private premises, shall correct the damages at no cost to the city. 
D.  In the event the damages are not corrected within ten days, the city shall cause the correction of the damages and shall charge the operator, or owner, occupant or person in charge of the property the cost of correcting the damage. In the event the costs remain unpaid following 30 days, it shall be entered on the tax roll as a special tax against the property. 
E.  In addition to the costs to correct damages, the operator, or the owner, occupant or person in charge of the property shall be subject to a penalty per occurrence as prescribed in Chapter 1.24. Each day after the ten days that the damages are not corrected, shall constitute a separate offense under this section. 
(Prior Code, § 6-2-16; Code 1998, § 12.04.150)

(Prior Code, § 6-2-17; Code 1998, § 12.04.160) 
Sec. 12.04.170. - Newspaper receptacles. 
A.  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to safeguard the beauty of the city while ensuring the rights of the individual to receive a newspaper in readable condition. 
B.  Newspaper Receptacle Defined. For the purpose of this section, a "newspaper receptacle" is any outside device designed for and/or used to receive newspapers, advertising flyers or similar printed materials delivered by a carrier. Included in this definition are such devices which may be freestanding or attached to the sides of buildings, posts, mailbox posts and/or other outside structures. 
C.  Restrictions. Newspaper receptacles are prohibited in public rights-of-way, except at the edge of the roadway or street. No more than one newspaper receptacle shall be placed per dwelling unit. No newspaper receptacle shall be placed on a lot other than the lot occupied by the dwelling without written permission of the lot owner. All newspaper receptacles shall be maintained in a presentable manner. 
D.  Color. All newspaper receptacles shall be of standard neutral color, brown or tan, as approved by the city. Permitted newspaper receptacles shall not display any advertising message, including, but not limited to, the name of a newspaper or flyer, but may display an identifying mark for each publisher using the receptacle not to exceed two inches by two inches in size. 
E.  Removal. Each publisher which has placed or places a newspaper receptacle pursuant to this section shall provide the occupier of the dwelling to which it is adjacent with a self-addressed postcard, printed in such a manner that the occupier may instruct the publisher to remove the newspaper receptacle. If the publisher receives instructions from the occupier to remove the newspaper receptacle, the publisher shall remove the newspaper receptacle within ten days of the receipt of the instructions. 
(Prior Code, § 6-2-18; Code 1998, § 12.04.170) 
Sec. 12.04.180. - Grass clippings. 
    All grass clippings from lawnmowing or other sources shall not be allowed to blow upon or accumulate upon any public street in the city where such grass clippings could wash into any storm sewer drainage inlet. 
(Prior Code, § 6-2-19; Code 1998, § 12.04.180) 
Sec. 12.04.190. - Street improvement assessments. 
A.  Methods of Paying. The abutting property owner shall pay for the construction of public improvements where special assessments are levied or charged, by paying such assessments under one of the following plans: 
1.  Payment in Full. By such owner filing the notice specified in Wis. Stats. § 66.0713 and paying such assessment in full prior to the next succeeding November 1. Upon acceptance of the particular public improvement and the election by the property owner to pay in full, the city administrator shall issue a certificate for collection. The city administrator shall then notify such owner that: 
a.  The amount is due. 
b.  If paid within 30 days of the notice, no interest shall be charged, otherwise interest shall accrue at a rate one percent higher than the current prevailing bank rate. 
c.  If not paid by the next succeeding November 1, such amount, plus interest to December 31, shall be placed on the next succeeding tax roll. 
2.  Five-Year Installment Plan. By such owner filing a notice similar to the notice specified in Wis. Stats. § 66.0713, the owner elects to pay such assessment in five annual installments. The first installment shall include a one-fifth portion of the principal of the assessment together with interest thereto at the rate of one percent higher than the current prevailing bank rate, from the date of acceptance by the city of such public improvement to the succeeding December 31, providing such acceptance was prior to November 1 of that year, otherwise such interest shall accrue to the next succeeding December 31 and be placed on the next succeeding tax roll. Each subsequent installment shall include a like proportion of the principal and one year's interest upon the unpaid portion of such assessment. The city administrator shall maintain a schedule of all five-year installment assessment plans and the payments made thereon. 
3.  Prorated Interest. After the time for making the election shall have expired, any property owner on an installment basis may pay all remaining installments, or any part thereof, together with interest at the rate of 11 percent per year through the month of such payment; providing, however, between November 1 and December 31 of each year the one installment with interest which is placed on the current tax roll shall be paid as shown on such tax roll, and the remaining principal installments may be paid without interest. 
B.  Applicability. The provisions for installment assessment payments shall be applicable only to assessments in excess of $500.00. 
C.  Written Notice Required. 
1.  The election to utilize any of the payment plans hereunder shall be made in writing by the property owner on forms prescribed by the city. 
2.  The city administrator, upon certification of the project, shall notify all property owners who have not made an election for payment under the provisions of this section that they have 30 days from the date of such acceptance and certification to pay the entire assessment, and if they fail to make such payment, then such assessment shall be payable over a period of five years under the provisions of this section. 
(Prior Code, § 6-2-20; Code 1998, § 12.04.190) 
Sec. 12.04.200. - Watercourses. 
A.  Definitions. 
1.  Project means a building or any other kind of construction whatsoever which will modify the existing topography of a parcel or parcels of land. 
2.  Watercourse means a natural or manmade channel through which water flows. For the purpose of this section, watercourses include, but are not limited to, culverts, ditches, swales, drain tiles, gutters, spillways, checks, inlet leads, inlet basins, drained parking lots and storm sewers. 
B.  Purpose. A watercourse is established for the purpose of providing surface water drainage for spring runoff, sump pump discharge, stormwater, artesian wells, fountains, springs or other clear water discharge. 
C.  Establishment. A watercourse shall be established or recognized by any of the following methods: 
1.  Naturally. Any watercourse created by the natural watercourse, whether navigable or not. 
2.  Conformance. Watercourses established as part of a new subdivision shall be constructed in conformance with Title 16. 
3.  Preexisting . Any watercourse, natural or manmade, which is generally recognized as having been used as such, shall be deemed a preexisting watercourse. 
4.  By Engineering Design. A watercourse may be created by the city engineer or his/her agent in the course of his/her duties, subject to approval of the common council. 
D.  Interference With. No person shall interfere with the operation of any watercourse by such actions as landscaping, damming, installation of inadequate water conduit or any other actions which would interfere with the intended operation of the watercourse. 
E.  Maintenance. 
1.  Private Property. It shall be the responsibility of every property owner to keep any watercourse passing through his/her property free and clear of any debris, vegetation, soil or anything else which would interfere with the intended operation of the watercourse. 
2.  Public Property. It shall be the responsibility of the city to maintain watercourses on public property. 
F.  New Building and Other Projects. For any project not already covered under Title 16, the applicant for project approval shall show a watercourse plan as an element of the project plan. The watercourse shall be designed to conduct water away from the project to an existing established watercourse. Plans are subject to approval by the city engineer or his/her agent. 
G.  Map. 
1.  The city engineer shall create and maintain a map on which established open channel watercourses are shown, subject to approval of the common council. 
2.  Watercourses that are part of the standard construction of city street rights-of-way such as ditches, swales and culverts, need not be shown on such map. 
(Prior Code, § 6-2-21; Code 1998, § 12.04.200) 
Sec. 12.04.210. - Bidder's proof of responsibility. 
    When public works contracts are required by law, the director of public works is required, pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0901, before delivering any form for bid proposals to require any person so bidding to submit a full and complete statement sworn to before an officer authorized by law to administer oaths of financial ability, equipment and experience in the work prescribed in such public contract and of such other matters as the city, or director of public works thereof, may require for the protection and welfare of the public in the performance of such contract. Such statement shall be written on a standard form of a questionnaire as adopted for such use by the city and shall be filed in the manner and place designated by the city not less than five days prior to the time set for opening of bids. The contents of such statements shall be confidential and shall not be disclosed except upon written order of such person furnishing the same or in cases of actions against the city by the bidders. 
State Law reference- Bidding for public works contracts, Wis. Stats. § 66.0901. 
(Prior Code, § 6-2-22; Code 1998, § 12.04.210(A)) 
Sec. 12.04.220. - Discharge of water onto public streets. 
A.  No person shall hereafter directly or indirectly cause any water from any sump pump, eaves trough, rainwater leader, downspout, cistern, overflow, surface water drain, air conditioning system, industrial cooling system or similar source to be drained or discharged onto any sidewalk or the traveled portion of any public street within the city, at any time during the year. 
B.  No person shall directly or indirectly cause any water from any sump pump, down spout, gutters, rainwater leader, air conditioning system or similar system to be discharged any closer than eight feet from the property line of the lot on which the water originates. Discharge piping may be run into the public right-of-way. If any water that is discharged onto private property or the public right-of-way should cause a situation that affects the traveled portion of the right-of-way, the person responsible for the property shall change the point of discharge so as to eliminate the situation in the traveled portion of the right-of-way. The director of public works and the chief of police shall be authorized to order such changes. 
C.  The owner of any building or residence within the city from which any water from any sump pump, eaves trough, rainwater leader, downspout, cistern, overflow, surface drain, air conditioning system, industrial cooling system or similar source is being drained or discharged in violation of Subsection A or B of this section shall cause such drainage to be discharged or eliminated within 90 days of city notice. The time period provided herein may be extended by the director of public works of the city upon written petition. The petition shall be brought within the original 90-day period. 
(Prior Code, § 6-2-23; Code 1998, § 12.04.220) 
CHAPTER 12.08. - GRADES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority relative to street grades, Wis. Stats. § 62.16. 

Sec. 12.08.010. - Establishment of grades. 
A.  Grades to be established. The grade of all streets, alleys and sidewalks shall be established by resolution by the common council, upon the recommendation of the Public Works Department, and the same recorded by the city administrator in his/her office. No street, alley or sidewalk shall be worked until the grade thereof is established. In all cases where the grade of sidewalks shall not have been specifically set by ordinance, the sidewalks shall be laid to the established grade of the street. All such grades heretofore established are confirmed. All grades and elevations fixed and established in the city shall be described in feet and decimals of a foot using U.S.G.S. datum. This datum has been established by the federal government in the city. 
B.  Sidewalk Grades. Whenever a street shall be improved for the first time or the grade thereof changed and the street improved so as to conform to the new grade, the grading of the sidewalk shall be considered a part of the improvement, shall be let by contract with the other work of improving such street, and the expense thereof shall be provided for and borne in all respects like that of improving the street, but the construction shall be done by the owners of the abutting lots or parcels of land or at their expense as hereinafter provided. Before such construction is commenced by the owners of the abutting lots or parcels of land, the common council, or its designee, shall, upon application by the respective owners for a sidewalk grade, cause such sidewalk grade to be established. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1-1; Code 1998, § 12.08.010) 
Sec. 12.08.020. - Alteration of grade prohibited. 
    No person shall alter the grade of any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground or any part thereof in the city by any means whatsoever unless authorized or instructed to do so by the common council, or Public Works Department. All such alterations of grade shall be recorded in the office of the city administrator. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1-2; Code 1998, § 12.08.020) 
Sec. 12.08.030. - Regulation of underground utilities. 
A.  Elevation. The grade or elevation of all underground construction shall be a minimum of three feet below the established grade of the street, alley, park, public property or easement. The three feet shall be measured between the top of the established grade and the top of the underground construction. 
B.  Approval of Location. The location of any and all such underground construction must have the approval of the Public Works Department. 
C.  Filing Plans. Complete plans for any such construction must be filed with and be approved by the Public Works Department before construction can begin. 
D.  Inspection. On request of the Public Works Department, the utility company must provide opportunity for city officials to check any construction before it may be covered. 
E.  Conflict with Other Utilities . If the grade or elevation herein set for the underground construction of utilities shall, in any instance, conflict with other existing utilities, the utility shall be required to lower the elevation of its underground construction at the election of the Public Works Department, and in accordance with its directions and specifications. 
F.  Establishment of Grade. At the request of the utility company, the Public Works Department shall, at the city's expense, give the utility company an established grade on any streets, alleys, public parks or easements where it proposes to install underground utilities. 
G.  Emergency. In case of an emergency, when immediate action is necessary in order to protect life or property, the utility company may proceed with underground construction subject to obtaining the approval of such work by the Public Works Department as soon thereafter as is reasonably possible. 
H.  Restoration of Surface. In the event of any such underground construction, the utility company shall leave the surface of the ground, or road, in the same condition as before the work was commenced, and in the event of its failure so to do, the city may proceed to place the surface of the ground or street in such condition at the utility company's expense. Such work shall comply with the provisions of Sections 12.04.030 and 12.04.240. 
I.  Non-Relief from Obligations. Compliance with this section does not relieve the utility company from any responsibility of any kind whatsoever by reason of the widening of the travelway, or any other improvements which may become necessary; nor does it relieve it from any liability of any kind or nature whatsoever. Compliance with this section shall not relieve the utility company from the responsibility or obligation of removing, relocating or moving any of its mains, pipes or property due to the opening, widening or improving of streets, or due to any other changes which may occur by reason of which such moving, relocation or removing may be necessary. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1-3; Code 1998, § 12.08.030) 
CHAPTER 12.12. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 12.12.010. - Definitions. 
A.  Class I driveway approach means a driveway approach which serves a single parcel of property located in a residential zoning district or business zoning district which is used for residential purposes. 
B.  Class II driveway approach means a driveway approach which serves property located in a commercial district which is not used primarily for residential purposes. 
C.  Class III driveway approach means a drive approach which serves business or manufacturing property and which is primarily used by buses or semitrailer trucks. 
D.  Curb cut means that section of concrete curb removed to permit the entrance and exit of vehicles from adjacent property and shall be measured at the entrance width including the allowable flare. 
E.  Director of public works also includes designees thereof. 
F.  Driveway approach means the entire area within a public right-of-way which is improved for motor vehicle traffic and which connects a private road or driveway to a public right-of-way which is improved for motor vehicle traffic. 
G.  Entrance means the point at which a driveway abuts the driveway approach. 
H.  Flare means the portion of a driveway approach which is wider at the street curb line than at the entrance. 
I.  Intersection turning area means the part of the street intersection included between the radius line used to connect the curb lines and the intersection of the curb line, if extended. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.010; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.020. - Permit required. 
A.  No person shall begin to construct, reconstruct, repair, alter or grade any sidewalk, curb, curb cut, driveway or street on the public streets without first obtaining a permit from the director of public works as provided by this chapter. 
B.  All permitted improvements must be completed by November 1 of the year the permit is issued unless prior arrangements have been made with the director of public works. Under no circumstances will the conformance deadline be extended beyond June 30 in the year following the year in which the permit was originally provided. 
C.  Uncompleted permits are subject to corrective action deemed necessary by the director of public works to protect the public rights-of-way, and the cost thereof shall be levied as a special charge against the abutting parcels of land. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.020; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.030. - Permit application. 
    An applicant for a permit hereunder shall file with the director of public works an application showing: 
A.  Name and address of the owner, or agent in charge, of the property abutting the proposed work area; 
B.  Location of the work area; 
C.  Attached plans showing details of the proposed alteration; 
D.  Such other information as the director of public works shall find reasonably necessary to the determination of whether a permit should be issued hereunder. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.030; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.040. - Standards for issuance of permit. 
1.  The director of public works shall issue a permit hereunder when he/she finds: 
A.  That the work shall be done according to the standard specifications of the city for public work of like character. The plans and specifications for the improvements are on file in the office of the city engineer; 
B.  That the operation will not unreasonably interfere with vehicular and pedestrian traffic, the demand and necessity for parking spaces, and the means of egress to and from the property affected and adjacent properties; 
C.  That the health, welfare and safety of the public will not be unreasonably impaired. 
2.  No building permit shall be issued for any new construction or for any type of building construction which requires driveways in any district unless a driveway permit is issued. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.040; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.050. - Supervision of director of public works. 
A.  All operations for which a permit is granted hereunder shall be under the direction and supervision of the director of public works or his/her designee. 
B.  The applicant shall notify the city engineering department representative's office prior to, during, and upon completion of, any of the foregoing work for an inspection thereof. Inspection of the work shall be done by the representative of the Public Works Department based on the criteria approved by the common council. The penalty for violating this chapter is set forth in section 12.12.140. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.050; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.060. - Order to alter driveway approach. 
A.  Whenever a driveway approach is altered or closed, the work shall be performed according to the plans and specifications for driveway approaches on file in the office of the city engineer. 
B.  Repair of defective approaches and curb cut returns. The director of public works may order an owner to repair, replace or remove any driveway approach or curb cut return that is unsafe, defective or insufficient and cause it to comply with this chapter. A copy of the order directing such work shall be served by registered mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service, or by publication as a Class 1 notice if the owner cannot reasonably be located. If the work is not done within 30 days after the date of notice, the city may perform the work and the cost thereof shall be levied as a special charge against the abutting parcel of land. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.060; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.070. - Driveway conditions and criteria. 
A.  Construction Defined. Construction of a driveway shall be defined as the actual excavation and/or placement of concrete, asphalt, or a non-permeable material intended to serve as a permanent drivable surface. 
B.  Interference with Street. No driveway apron shall extend out into the street further than the back of curb or edge of existing road pavement. 
C.  Surface Water Drainage. Where necessary to provide for adequate surface water drainage the property owner shall provide, install and maintain any necessary culvert pipe at their own expense. 
D.  The location of drive approaches shall be subject to the following: 
1.  Driveway opening shall be located at least 40 feet from a block corner with the exception of single-family and two-family driveway openings which shall be located at least 25 feet from a block corner. The block corner shall be the intersection of the edge of pavement or curb of the two streets. 
2.  All driveway approaches shall be so located as to provide adequate sight distance in both directions along the street for safe access to the street accordingly; from a point six feet behind the edge of street pavement or curb a distance in feet of 71/2 times the posted speed limit. 
3.  The maximum and minimum specifications for driveway approaches shall be as follows: 
Class I Maximum permitted width of entrance 25 feet Minimum permitted width of entrance 13 feet Maximum permitted curb cut 30 feet Minimum permitted curb cut 18 feet Minimum setback for tapering driveway to meet 25 feet at property line is 5 feet from sidewalk Class II Maximum permitted width of entrance 30 feet Maximum permitted width of curb cut 40 feet Class III Maximum permitted width of entrance 40 feet Maximum permitted curb cut 70 feet  
  
4.  Frequency: 
a.  One per residential property. 
b.  Two per commercial unit if frontage is greater than 300 feet. 
c.  Additional driveway warranted if total ingress/egress volume exceeds 1,000 vpd. 
5.  Spacing: 
a.  105-foot minimum for 25 miles per hour speed limit. 
b.  125-foot minimum for 30 miles per hour speed limit. 
c.  150-foot minimum for 35 miles per hour speed limit. 
d.  185-foot minimum for 40 miles per hour speed limit. 
e.  220-foot minimum for 45 miles per hour speed limit 
6.  Curb radius: 
a.  20-foot minimum. 
E.  Any time a parcel of land is cleared of existing surface improvement, the driveways serving that parcel should be cleared or reconstructed to conform to the guidelines set forth herein. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.080; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.080. - Two-family driveway requirements. 
    Individual driveways for two-family residences may be separate or adjoining. Individual drives for two-family structures are limited to the Class 1 residential standard of 25 feet width at the property line and 30 feet at the curb cut. Adjoining driveways are limited to 50 feet at the property line and 55 feet at the curb cut. The adjoining driveways may be separated by a two-foot green space extending the full length of the driveway from the property line to the garage/parking space, increasing the width at the property line to 52 feet and a maximum of 57 feet at the curb cut. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.085; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.090. - Unusual conditions. 
    The planning commission is authorized to grant in writing, variances from the strict application of driveway conditions and criteria, provided it is determined that the following conditions are present: 
A.  The exception or variance desired arises from peculiar physical conditions not ordinarily existing in similar districts in the city, or is due to the nature of the business or operation on the abutting property; 
B.  That the granting of the permit for the exception or variance will not adversely affect the rights of adjacent property owners or tenants; 
C.  That exception or variance desired is not against the public interest, particularly safety, convenience and general welfare; 
D.  That the strict application of the terms of this chapter will place unnecessary hardship on the property owner or tenant. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.090; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.100. - Pave granular drives. 
    All newly constructed or altered driveway approaches shall be of concrete, hot mix asphalt, or non-permeable material intended to serve as a permanent drivable surface. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.100; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.110. - Concrete aprons with sidewalks. 
    When city sidewalks are installed on the right-of-way behind concrete curb and gutter, the property owner shall construct the drive aprons in the public right-of-way to be of adequate depth and design as determined by the director of public works within 60 days of the placement of the sidewalk. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.110; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.120. - Roadside ditches. 
A.  No roadside drainage ditches shall be blocked or filled by any property owner, contractor or entity without an alternate, approved by the director of public works to transport runoff and sub-base road drainage. 
B.  Installation of ditch culverts under drives and streets shall require no less than a one-foot rise to a three-foot run on both the upstream and downstream ends of the culverts. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.120; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.130. - Permit fees. 
    A fee will only be charged when a driveway approach is being done and that fee will be established by the common council and kept on file in the office of the city clerk. The fee shall be doubled upon failure to obtain a permit before construction of a driveway begins. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.130; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.135. - Interference with street structures. 
    No driveway approach shall interfere with any facilities (utilities) located in the road right-of-way. The owner shall be responsible for all costs associated with the relocation of such structures, and the cost thereof shall be levied as a special charge against the abutting parcels of land. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.135; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 12.12.140. - Violations; penalties. 
    A fine of $35.00 per day for not meeting the requirements of this chapter will be imposed by the city public works director and/or his/her designee. The fines shall be imposed through a per day forfeiture, citation served on the property owner. The City of Omro reserves the right to bring property into compliance and charges will be assessed against the property. 
(Code 1998, § 12.12.140; Ord. No. 463, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
CHAPTER 12.16. - STREET USE PERMITS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to grant street privileges, Wis. Stats. § 66.0425. 

Sec. 12.16.010. - Purpose. 
    The streets in possession of the city are primarily for the use of the public in the ordinary way. However, under proper circumstances, the common council may grant a permit for street use, subject to reasonable municipal regulation and control. Therefore, this chapter is enacted to regulate and control the use of streets pursuant to a street use permit to the end that the health, safety and general welfare of the public and the good order of the city can be protected and maintained. 
(Prior Code, § 7-7-1(a); Code 1998, § 12.16.010) 
Sec. 12.16.020. - Application. 
    A written application for a street use permit by persons or groups desiring the same shall be made on a form provided by the city administrator and shall be filed with the city administrator. The application shall set forth the following information regarding the proposed street use: 
A.  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant or applicants; 
B.  If the proposed street use is to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization and of the authorizing responsible heads of such organization; 
C.  The name, address and telephone number of the person or persons who will be responsible for conducting the proposed use of the street; 
D.  The date and duration of time for which the requested use of the street is proposed to occur; 
E.  An accurate description of that portion of the street proposed to be used; 
F.  The approximate number of persons for whom use of the proposed street area is requested; 
G.  The proposed use, described in detail, for which the street use permit is requested. 
(Prior Code, § 7-7-1(b); Code 1998, § 12.16.020) 
Sec. 12.16.030. - Representative at meeting. 
    The person or representative of the group making application for a street use permit shall be present when the common council gives consideration to the granting of the street use permit to provide any additional information which is reasonably necessary to make a fair determination as to whether a permit should be granted. 
(Prior Code, § 7-7-1(c); Code 1998, § 12.16.030) 
Sec. 12.16.040. - Review by chief of police and director of public works. 
    Before any application for a street use permit is considered by the common council, the application shall be reviewed by the director of public works and chief of police for their recommendation as to the affect that the temporary closing of the street will have on the public safety and traffic movement in the area during the time the street may be closed. 
(Prior Code, § 7-7-1(d); Code 1998, § 12.16.040) 
Sec. 12.16.050. - Mandatory denial of street use permit. 
1.  An application for a street use permit shall be denied if: 
A.  The proposed street use is primarily for private or commercial gain (auctions are exempted); 
B.  The proposed street use would violate any federal or state law or any ordinance of the city; 
C.  The proposed street use will substantially hinder the movement of police, fire or emergency vehicles, constituting a risk to persons or property; 
D.  The application for a street use permit does not contain the information required above; 
E.  The application requests a period for the use of the street in excess of six hours; 
F.  The proposed use could equally be held in a public park or other location. 
2.  In addition to the requirement that the application for a street use permit shall be denied, as hereinabove set forth, the common council may deny a permit for any other reason or reasons if it concludes that the health, safety and general welfare of the public cannot adequately be protected and maintained if the permit is granted. 
(Prior Code, § 7-7-1(e); Code 1998, § 12.16.050) 
Sec. 12.16.060. - Permit fee. 
    Each application for a street use permit shall be accompanied by a fee paid in accordance with the fee schedule on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Prior Code, § 7-7-1(f); Code 1998, § 12.16.060) 
Sec. 12.16.070. - Consent to issuance of street use permit. 
    In addition to the fee required by the section 12.16.060, each application for a street use permit, except for parades or races sponsored by civic, youth or scout organizations which have been in existence for at least six months, shall be accompanied by a petition designating the proposed area of the street to be used and time for the proposed use, the petition to be signed by not less than 75 percent of the residents over 18 years of age residing along that portion of the street designated for the proposed use. 
(Prior Code, § 7-7-1(g); Code 1998, § 12.16.070) 
Sec. 12.16.080. - Insurance. 
    The applicant for a street use permit may be required to indemnify, defend and hold the city and its employees and agents harmless against all claims, liability, loss, damage or expense incurred by the city on account of any injury to or death of any person or any damage to property caused by or resulting from the activities for which the permit is granted. As evidence of the applicant's ability to perform the conditions of the permit, the applicant may be required to furnish a certificate of comprehensive general liability insurance with the city. The applicant may be required to furnish a performance bond prior to being granted the permit. 
(Prior Code, § 7-7-1(h); Code 1998, § 12.16.080) 
Sec. 12.16.090. - Termination of a street use permit. 
    A street use permit for an event in progress may be terminated by the police department if the health, safety and welfare of the public appears to be endangered by activities generated as a result of the event or the event is in violation of any of the conditions of the permits or ordinances of the city. The chief of police has the authority to revoke a permit or terminate an event in progress if the event organizers fail to comply with any of the regulations in the street use policy or conditions stated in the permit. 
(Prior Code, § 7-7-1(i); Code 1998, § 12.16.090) 
CHAPTER 12.20. - TREE PLANTING 

Sec. 12.20.010. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to cause the orderly planting of trees, within the corporate limits of the city, under or near utility or high power lines on front, rear and side yard terraces of residential homes and commercial businesses. 
(Code 1998, § 12.20.010; Ord. No. 329(part), 1994) 
Sec. 12.20.020. - Legislative intent. 
    It is intended by this chapter to establish regulations that regulate the planting of trees on the front, rear and side yard terraces of residential homes and commercial businesses located in the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1998, § 12.20.020; Ord. No. 329(part), 1994) 
Sec. 12.20.030. - Conflict of provisions. 
    In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements and shall be deemed a limitation or repeal of any other power granted by the Wisconsin Statutes. Where any terms or the requirements of this chapter may be inconsistent or conflicting, the more restrictive requirements or interpretation shall apply. Where a provision of this chapter is required by Wisconsin Statutes or by Wisconsin Administrative Code, and where the chapter provision is unclear, the provision shall be interpreted in light of the Wisconsin Statutes and the Wisconsin Administrative Code in effect on the date of the adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter, or in effect on the date of the most recent text amendment to this chapter. 
(Code 1998, § 12.20.030; Ord. No. 329(part), 1994) 
Sec. 12.20.040. - Applicability. 
    The requirements of this chapter apply to all persons and/or entities within the city corporate limits, Winnebago County, Wisconsin. 
(Code 1998, § 12.20.040; Ord. No. 329(part), 1994) 
Sec. 12.20.050. - Administration. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be administered by the common council or its designee. 
(Code 1998, § 12.20.050; Ord. No. 329(part), 1994) 
Sec. 12.20.060. - Planting conditions; permit required. 
A.  All trees planted in accordance with Section 12.20.090 must be by permit. Any tree species not specified on the permit or improperly planted shall be removed at the direction of the appointed agent for the city. No permit will be issued for the following trees: Box Elder, Silver Maple, and any member of the poplar family of tree. 
B.  The permittee agrees to hold harmless the city against all claims, demands, liabilities, damages or any other costs which may accrue as a result of the issuance and use of a permit. 
(Code 1998, § 12.20.060; Ord. No. 329(part), 1994) 
Sec. 12.20.070. - Planting standards. 
A.  Each tree shall be planted no deeper than it grew in a nursery as determined by the soil line on the trunk of the tree. Any broken or long roots should be pruned off. Planting should allow six inches of clearance around the tree's root system. 
B.  Soil backfill should be added gradually allowing the tree's roots to assume their natural position. The soil backfill shall be tamped occasionally during planting leaving a dish-shaped impression in the soil at the surface. Water well after planting and very heavily every tenth day after planting. Mulch may be placed around the tree base. Grass should not be allowed to grow within one foot of the tree trunk. 
C.  Usually, newly planted trees should not be fertilized until the second growing season. Remove all broken branches but do not prune the central leader. 
D.  Support by use of stakes should be used when needed. The supporting ties should be fastened to the tree so as to not cut or nick the tree trunk. 
(Code 1998, § 12.20.070; Ord. No. 329(part), 1994) 
Sec. 12.20.080. - Suggested shade tree species. 
    Where no utility wires are located, or a tree is not planted on a city street terrace, no permit shall be required. The following trees, recommended to be spaced every 35 feet, are permitted: Norway Maples (Colummar, Emerald Queen, Crimson King, Superform, Royal Red, etc.); Sugar Maples; Kentucky Coffee Trees; Green Ash (Marshall Seedless, Newpoert, Summit); White Ash (Autumm Purple); Lindens (American, Little Leaf, Chancelor, Greenspire, Redmond); Thornless Honey Locust (Shademaster, Skyline); Bur Oak; American Beech; Hackberry. 
(Code 1998, § 12.20.080; Ord. No. 329(part), 1994) 
Sec. 12.20.090. - Required shade tree species. 
    Any tree planted under a utility wire or on a city street terrace shall be by permit only. Minimum spacing between trees shall be 20 feet. Permitted trees are as follows: Amur Maple (tree form); Apple Service Berry; Hornbeam; Thornless Hawethorn; Flowering Crab (American Beauty, Delgo, Flame, Pink Spires, Radiant, Silver Moon and Tschonoski); Ironwood; Canada Red Cherry; Callery Pear; Japanese Tree Lilac. 
(Code 1998, § 12.20.090; Ord. No. 329(part), 1994) 
Sec. 12.20.100. - Violations; penalties and enforcement. 
A.  Any person who violates a provision of this chapter shall be provided with a violation correction notice that shall include the name of the property owner; address of the subject property; type of violation with reference to the proper Omro city ordinance; what type of action must be done by the property owner to remedy the violation; and the amount of time allowed to remedy the violation, but not less than ten days. 
B.  In the event the property owner fails to comply with a violation correction notice within the requisite time, a citation may be issued by city to collect a forfeiture. The issuance of a citation shall not preclude proceeding under any other ordinance or law relating to the same or any other matter shall not preclude the issuance of a citation under this section. 
C.  Penalties for violating this chapter may be assessed as follows: any person who violates this chapter shall be required to forfeit $50.00 for a first violation, $100.00 for a second violation, and not more than $500.00 for a third or subsequent violation, plus allowable court costs and costs of abatement incurred by the city. 
(Code 1998, § 12.20.100; Ord. No. 329(part), 1994) 
CHAPTER 12.24. - PARKS AND NAVIGABLE WATERS 

Sec. 12.24.005. - Duties of the director of community services in relation to the parks department. 
    The director shall be responsible to promulgate the rules and regulations for the management, operation and control of parks and related facilities and recommend appropriate fees and deposits to the office of the city administrator to ensure the safety, protection and well-being of the properties operated by the parks department. The director shall be governed and work within the guidelines provided by the parks committee as authorized under the Omro Municipal Code. 
(Code 1998, § 12.24.005; Ord. No. 385, § 1(part), 2003) 
Sec. 12.24.010. - Park regulations. 
A.  Purpose and Definition. In order to protect the parks, parkways, recreational facilities and conservancy areas within the city from injury, damage or desecration, these regulations are enacted. The term "park" as hereinafter used in this chapter is defined to mean all lands and water heretofore and hereafter acquired by the City of Omro for park or recreational purposes, or placed under the jurisdiction of the parks department, and includes, without limitation, parks, parkways, recreational facilities and structures, watercourses which are or may be located within any area dedicated to the public use as a park, playgrounds, swimming pools, any privately owned lands, the use of which has been granted or leased to the city for park, recreational, or like public purposes, or conservancy areas within the city limits. 
B.  Specific Regulations. 
1.  Littering Prohibited. No person shall litter, dump or deposit any rubbish, refuse, earth or other material in any park. It is unlawful for any person to leave, throw or break any bottle, box, refuse or other object, except in clearly marked refuse receptacles provided for that purpose. Where receptacles for rubbish and refuse are not provided, the person or group responsible for it shall carry all waste away from the park. It is unlawful for any person to throw, discharge, or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the water of any fountain, pond, lake, stream, river or other body of water or on the ice thereof, in or adjacent to any park, any substance, matter, or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in "pollution" of such waters as defined by the department of natural resources. 
2.  Sound Devices and Amplification Systems. Most park facilities are located within residential areas where a certain level of peace and quiet is expected and will be enforced. Therefore, it is unlawful to use public address systems, amplifiers or any other amplification device, including amplified music, in any park or recreation area after 10:00 p.m., except as provided herein. "Amplifier" or "amplification device" in this section means any machine or device for the amplification of human voice, music or any other sound, but shall not be construed to include standard vehicle radios or stereos when installed and when heard only by occupants of the vehicles in which the unit is installed, while occupying that vehicle. The use of radios, stereos or other similar devices is expressly permitted, except that the volume of sound shall be controlled so that it is not unreasonably loud, disturbing or of such character, intensity or duration that it is disturbing to any person within the range of audibility. The human speech or music amplified shall not be profane, lewd, indecent or slanderous in nature. This section shall not be construed to limit the authority of the Omro Police Department to respond to complaints and to take any appropriate action in response thereto. 
a.  Exemptions. 
1.  An exemption is allowed for an amplified sound or music activity that provides a substantial benefit to the public, including, but not limited to, parades, sporting events, special community events, public concerts, fireworks displays, and one-day nonprofit festivals that are open to the general public. 
2.  An exemption is allowed for park pavilion rentals on Friday and Saturday nights, allowing for amplified sound or music activity until 11:00 p.m. Proof of rental permit must be provided upon request. 
b.  Variance. A variance permit may be issued upon request, provided that the activity producing noise is necessary to promote public health and/or welfare and reasonable steps are taken to keep noise at the lowest practical level. The criteria for granting of a variance shall be based upon finding of all of the following: 
i.  The variance will provide a substantial benefit to the public generally and be open to public attendance; 
ii.  The source, nature and duration of the proposed sound is not contrary to public health and/or welfare; 
iii.  Conditions exist that are beyond the control of the person applying for the variance; and 
iv.  No other alternative facility or method of operation for the event is available to the applicant. A variance will not be issued if there are reasonable alternative locations for the event available to the applicant. 
3.  Bill Posting. No person shall post, paste, fasten, paint or attach any placard, bill, notice, sign or advertising matter upon any structure, tree or other natural object in any park, except park regulations and other signs authorized by the parks department, or designees thereof. 
4.  Throwing Stones and Missiles Prohibited. No person shall throw stones or other missiles in or into any park except standard playground equipment designed and used as a throwing device, such as balls and Frisbees. 
5.  Removal of Park Equipment Prohibited. No person shall remove benches, bleachers, seats, tables or other park equipment from any park unless prior written permission of the director of community services, or designee thereof, is obtained. 
6.  Trapping. "Trapping" when used in this section means and includes the taking, or attempting to take, of any wild animal by means of setting or operating any device, mechanism or contraption that is designated, built or made to close upon, hold fast or otherwise capture a wild animal or animals. The trapping of wild animals is prohibited in city parks, unless authorized by the director of community services or designee thereof, or under the direction of the department of natural resources or its designees. 
7.  Making of Fires. No person shall start, tend or maintain a fire except in personal grills or designated fireplaces or fire pits, unless permission is granted to allow fires in other areas by the director of community services or designees thereof and upon proper notification to the fire department. Personal grills shall be used only in designated picnic areas. The use of personal grills is permitted, provided lawns and vegetation are not endangered. Unburned fuel and ashes shall be disposed of in a designated container in such a manner as to prevent fire or damage to any park property. Fires must be attended at all times, safely distinguished and remnants disposed of prior to vacating city park property. 
8.  Protection of Park Property. 
a.  No person shall kill, injure or disturb or attempt to kill, injure or disturb waterfowl, birds or animals, wild or domestic, within any park, except as permitted by this section. No person shall climb any tree or remove flowers or fruit, wild or cultivated, or break, cut down, trample upon, remove or in any manner injure, deface, write upon or ill use any tree, shrub, flower, flower bed, turf, soil, sand, water fountain, ornament, building, structure, apparatus, bench, table, official notice, sign, fence or other property within any park. 
b.  No person shall deface, throw stones, pebbles or other debris in any of the toilets, bubblers or other sanitary facilities located in any city park; or deface by drawing with crayon, chalk, paint or anything else on any of the buildings or equipment at any city park; or deface the equipment by means of a sharp instrument. 
9.  Motorized Vehicles. Except for authorized maintenance vehicles, no person shall operate an unlicensed or licensed motorized vehicle outside of areas specifically designated as parking areas or areas where the operation of such vehicles are specifically permitted. Motor vehicles are restricted to the roads and drives and parking areas. No person shall drive any motor driven vehicle upon the grass or trail or park any place other than upon the established roadways and parking lots unless authorized to do so by the director of community services or designee thereof. No motor vehicles of any nature may be used on the seeded areas except vehicles which have been granted permission by the director, or designee thereof, and have police department authorization for shows, rides or exhibits and then only for the purpose of loading and unloading. 
10.  Snowmobiles. No person shall operate a snowmobile or other motorized recreational vehicle in a city park except in designated areas. Snowmobiles or other motorized recreational vehicles shall only be operated on designated trails. 
11.  Speed Limit. No person shall operate any vehicle in a city park in excess of ten miles per hour unless otherwise posted. 
12.  Reckless Driving in Parks Prohibited. No person shall operate a motor vehicle in a reckless manner in any of the public parks of the city. No person shall endanger the safety of any person or property by the negligent operation of a vehicle or cause bodily harm to any person by the negligent operation of a vehicle and in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 346.62(1). 
13.  Dogs and Domesticated Animals. Dogs are allowed on-leash within all city-operated parks during normal park operational hours, except park areas as specifically excluded per Section 6.04.110A, Prohibited Areas for Animals, which designates that a person owning or in charge of any animal shall not permit such animal to be upon city-operated beaches, city-operated cemeteries, sports fields, ball parks, and within or immediately surrounding the Omro Family Aquatic Center or any city park sand based playground area. 
a.  All owners of authorized animals brought onto city park property must be in compliance with all animal control provisions as set forth within the Omro Municipal Code and in accordance with all of the following regulations: 
i.  The dog must be on a chain, rope, cord or leash of a strength that allows for the reasonable control and containment of such animal by the owner or person in charge of such dog; 
ii.  The length of the chain, rope, cord or leash shall not exceed six feet when the owner or keeper and the dog are within any city park or when proceeding along any pedestrian sidewalk, or transportation corridor; 
iii.  The dog is licensed as required by Section 6.04.030 and is wearing a valid rabies vaccination tag as required by Section 6.04.140; 
iv.  The owner or keeper of the dog shall have in his/her immediate possession an appropriate device for scooping excrement and and/or an appropriate depository for the transmission of excrement to a receptacle located upon property owned or possessed by such person. This subsection shall not apply to owners or persons in charge of animals assisting visually-impaired, hearing-impaired or mobility-impaired persons; and 
v.  The owner or keeper of the dog shall remove and dispose of feces in compliance with Section 6.04.090. This subsection shall not apply to owners or persons in charge of animals assisting visually-impaired, hearing-impaired or mobility-impaired persons. 
b.  The provisions of this Subsection 13 shall not apply to: 
i.  Animals as provided in Wis. Stats. § 106.52(1)(fm), (3)(am)1.a; 
ii.  Dogs used by or under the auspices of the City of Omro Police Department or the Winnebago County Sherriff's Department in the course of official police business. 
c.  The director of public works shall cause signs to be posted in parks or park areas where dogs are permitted or prohibited. 
14.  Horse and Carriages. No person shall ride a horse or drive a horse-driven vehicle in any city-operated park, except on roads or designated bridle paths unless approval of the chief of police and the director of community services, or designee thereof, is first obtained. It is unlawful for any person to ride a horse or drive a horse-driven vehicle in a careless, negligent or reckless manner, which may endanger the safety and well-being of others. 
15.  Feeding of Geese, Waterfowl and Animals. It is strictly prohibited to feed geese, gulls, waterfowl or other nondomesticated animals within any city park. No person shall feed or provide nourishment to any waterfowl or nondomesticated animal within any park, nor attempt to domesticate any animal within any city park. 
16.  Removing Tree Protectors. No person shall remove any device, placed on or around a tree located in any city park that is used primarily for the protection or growth guidance of trees or shrubs. 
17.  Golfing and Sporting Activities. No golfing or practicing golf in city parks or recreation areas shall be allowed. No person shall participate in golf, tennis, or archery in any city park, except upon areas specifically designated for such purposes. 
18.  Fees and Charges. The common council, upon the recommendation of the parks committee, shall have the authority to establish such fees and security deposits as deemed necessary for use of any park facility, shelter, boat launch, watercraft mooring and docking facilities, or land area. It is unlawful to use such land areas or designated park facilities without payment of such fee or security deposit when required. The schedule of rental facilities and respective fees as established by the common council, shall be on file in the office of the city clerk, and are adopted by reference. 
19.  Firearms; Hunting and Weapons. Hunting, possessing or discharging of a weapon of any kind, for any purpose, including hunting, is prohibited in all city parks. Specifically, the use of firearms, air guns, paint guns, bow and arrow, slingshots, knives, swords, explosives, fireworks and weapons of every character, except in areas authorized by the chief of police and the director of community services or designees thereof. 
20.  Fish Cleaning. No person shall engage in the act of cleaning fish in park shelters, toilet facilities or picnic areas or on any public or park property. Cleaning fish on any park property is strictly prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to dispose of any fish remains, carcasses or entrails in a city park's refuse container. 
21.  Vendors Restricted. No person shall sell, vend or give away in any city park any article of merchandise whatsoever, without a written permit from the parks committee. It is unlawful for any person, organization, group, or association to vend, sell, peddle, or offer for sale any foods, refreshments, commodities, services or articles within any city park, except by concession agreement authorization, or authorization by the city council for major operations, or by the authorization of the director of community services for minor operations. Daily or seasonal vendor permits are required. Daily permits, for one-day events, may be obtained from the office of the city administrator upon authorization of the director of community services or designees thereof. Seasonal vendor permits may be obtained by the office of the city administrator upon formal approval of the Omro common council. Vending permit fees shall be established upon approval of the Omro common council and shall be kept on file in the office of the city administrator. 
22.  Smoking and Tobacco Products . No person shall smoke or hold a lighted cigarette, cigar or pipe in any no smoking area within any park, or in any other area in any park where notices prohibiting smoking are posted. It is unlawful for any person to use cigarettes, cigars, pipes or chewing tobacco within the boundaries of a designated playground structure or play area or to dispose of byproducts on or near playground perimeters. Chewing tobacco byproducts shall not be expelled onto any park property or into any park refuse container. This section shall not be construed to limit the authority of the Omro Police Department to control underage tobacco usage. 
23.  Camping. No person shall camp in any city park in any automobile, any vehicle which has accommodations for sleeping, except watercraft possessing a valid permit for overnight docking, or in any tent or sleeping bag in the open, or in any manner unless authorized to do so by a waiver issued by the director of community services or designee thereof. Watercrafts, that have a valid permit to dock overnight in designated mooring areas, are not included, but all persons must camp within the confines of the watercraft. No person authorized to dock a watercraft vehicle overnight is allowed to camp anywhere on shore in the city park. 
24.  Interference with Permittee. No person shall, in any manner, harass, disturb or interfere with persons holding written permits granted by the City of Omro and their authorized agents for the use of parks, shelter areas, designated overnight watercraft mooring spaces, boat launches or any other park facilities. 
25.  Swimming Limitations. No person shall swim, bathe or wade in any of the waters of the Fox River or its associated channels and tributaries within the city limits. This includes, but is not limited to, either swimming or bathing in the waters of the lagoons at Scott Park or Miller Park, or swimming in the Fox River from the shores off any city-owned property. 
(Prior Code, § 12-1-1; Code 1998, § 12.24.010; Ord. No. 392, 2005: Ord. No. 385, § 1(part), 2003; Ord. No. 446, 6-1-2010; Ord. No. 459, § 1, 9-3-2013) 
Sec. 12.24.020. - Operation of remote or radio-controlled toys or devices prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to fly, operate or make use of any remote- or radio-controlled model airplane, helicopter, vehicle or any other such device in, over or upon any street, park or other public property except in areas specifically designated and posted for such purpose and with the consent of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 12-1-2; Code 1998, § 12.24.020; Ord. No. 385, § 1(part), 2003; Ord. No. 449, § 1, 1-18-2011) 
Sec. 12.24.030. - Turf protection on public property. 
    Except as authorized by the director of community services or designees thereof, no person shall dig into the turf of any city-owned park or recreational property for any purposes whatsoever or remove any trees or flowers. Absent authorization by the director of community services or designees thereof, the use of metal detectors and digging for buried objects on city parks or recreational property is prohibited. 
(Prior Code, § 12-1-3; Code 1998, § 12.24.030; Ord. No. 385, § 1(part), 2003) 
Sec. 12.24.040. - Park hours. 
A.  Park Closing Hours . All city parks shall be closed from 12:00 midnight until 6:00 a.m. The director of community services or designee thereof may approve of the conduct of functions within the parks beyond 12:00 midnight by private organizations or individuals. In granting such approval, the director of community services or designee thereof shall designate the area in which the function shall be carried on and shall indicate the person responsible for the conduct of such function. No person shall be in any city park between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., except in compliance with this section. 
B.  Exceptions. 
1.  The regular closing hours of the city parks do not apply to persons having permission from the city to be present in the city parks during closed hours on specific days and for specific purposes. 
2.  The regular closing hours of the city parks apply to persons in attendance at a regularly scheduled ball game at any city ball diamond. The Omro Area Athletic Association ballpark shall be vacated, closed and the field lights turned off by 12:00 midnight. All play must be suspended and no innings shall commence after 11:30 p.m. 
3.  The regular closing hours of the city parks do not apply to persons launching fishing boats or watercraft for other water-related activities. 
4.  The regular closing hours of the city parks do not apply to persons actively fishing, and their designated vehicle thereof. 
C.  Emergency Park Closing and Opening. The chief of police, parks committee or common council will have full authority to open and close any park, facility or area because of weather condition, physical condition, conduction of a city function or related event, construction, or when in the interest of public safety, it is deemed necessary. 
(Prior Code, § 12-1-4; Code 1998, § 12.24.040; Ord. No. 385, § 1(part), 2003) 
Sec. 12.24.050. - Reservation of park space. 
A.  Policy on Reservation. 
1.  General Policy. City-owned park and park facilities and shelter areas are primarily for the nonexclusive use of the residents and visitors of the city. However, under proper circumstances, exclusive use of the same or parts thereof may be permitted. This section is intended to regulate exclusive use of municipally-owned parks, park facilities, park shelters or parts thereof. 
2.  Fees. The fees for reservations shall be as established by the common council upon the recommendation of the parks committee. The common council, upon recommendation of the parks committee may waive all permit fees for exclusive usage of parks' facilities. 
B.  Reservation of Park Space. A responsible person, age 18 or over, or group, firm, organization, partnership or corporation may reserve the use of a park facility or a park shelter by written application filed with the office of the city administrator for a permit for exclusive use of the same. The office of the city administrator shall issue permits for exclusive use of a portion of a park, park shelter or park facility, while the Omro common council shall issue permits for the exclusive use of an entire city park. All reservations shall be made on application forms in the office of the city administrator and shall be on a first-come, first-served basis; provided, however, that any city-based community or civic group may make reservations for dates used by it in past years on a continuing basis, at any time. Reservation of a designated area shall give the party to whom reserved the right to use such area to the exclusion of others for and during the period of reservation. Areas not reserved shall be open to use by all. 
C.  Application. Applications shall be filed at least 30 days prior to the date on which the exclusive use of the entire park is requested, or at least three days prior to the date on which a park shelter, park facility, aquatic center or any portion of a park is to be used, and shall set forth the following information regarding the proposed exclusive use: 
1.  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant; 
2.  If the exclusive use is proposed for a group, firm, organization, partnership or corporation, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the same and the responsible and authorized heads or partners of the same; 
3.  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be responsible for the use of the park, area or facility; 
4.  The date when the exclusive use is requested and the hours of the proposed exclusive date; 
5.  The anticipated number of persons to use the park, area or facility; 
6.  Any additional information, which the director of community services or city administrator's office finds reasonably necessary to determine whether a permit shall be issued; and 
7.  Receipt of a nonrefundable fee and a refundable security deposit along with a signed permit application. 
D.  Action on Application. The office of the city administrator shall act promptly on all applications for permits for exclusive park use after consulting with the applicant, if necessary. 
E.  Reasons for Denial. Applicants under this section may be denied for any of the following reasons: 
1.  If it is for a use which would involve a violation of federal or state law or any provision of this Code; 
2.  If the granting of the permit would conflict with another permit already granted or for which application is already pending; 
3.  If the application does not contain the information required by Subsection C of this section; 
4.  If the application is made less than the required days in advance of the scheduled exclusive use; 
5.  If it is for a use of the park or park facility at a date and time when, in addition to the proposed use, anticipated exclusive use by others of the park or park facility is expected and would be seriously adversely affected; 
6.  If the law enforcement requirements of the exclusive use will require so large a number of persons as to prevent adequate law enforcement to the park, park facility or shelter area involved or of the rest of the city; or 
7.  If the exclusive use will reasonably create a substantial risk of injury to persons or damage to property. 
F.  Indemnification. Prior to granting any permit for exclusive use of the park, the city may require the permittee to file evidence of good and sufficient sureties, insurance in force or other evidence of adequate financial responsibility, running to the city and such other third parties as may be injured or damaged, in an amount depending upon the likelihood of injury or damage as a direct and proximate result of the exclusive use sufficient to indemnify the city and such third parties as may be injured or damaged thereby, caused by the permittee, its agents or participants. 
G.  Permit Not Required for City Activity. A permit is not required for exclusive use of the park or a park facility sponsored by the city. 
H.  Permit Revocation. The chief of police may revoke a permit already issued if it is deemed that such action is justified by an actual or potential emergency due to weather, fire, riot, other catastrophe or likelihood of a breach of the peace or by a major change in the conditions forming the basis of the issuance of the permit. 
I.  Reserved Permit Cancellation. The permit fee for the exclusive use of park facilities will not be refunded if a cancellation occurs. The security deposit portion, when required, may be returned if the park facility is not used or is vacated in the proper state of cleanliness and no damage to property has occurred. The director of community services, or designee thereof, shall decide when the security deposit will be retained and for what specific reason. Mooring fees collected for reserved sites are nonrefundable if a cancellation occurs. 
J.  Form of Permit. Each permit shall be in a form prescribed by the city and shall designate the park, park facility or shelter area involved, date, hours of the exclusive use, purpose of the exclusive use and the name of the person, group, firm, organization, partnership or corporation to which the permit is issued. 
K.  Class B Fermented Malt Beverage Licenses. When fermented malt beverages are sold at any event authorized by this section, a valid temporary Class "B" fermented malt beverage license and/or temporary "Class B" wine license must be obtained from the City of Omro. The licenses shall be obtained according to the provisions of Chapter 5.08 and must be in full compliance of the same Chapter 5.08 and Wis. Stats. § 125.26(6). The person who filed the original license must hold the license application and shall be posted at the site and presented to any law enforcement officer upon request. All applicable license fees, and any corresponding administration fees necessary for conducting the required background checks, must be received prior to issuance of any temporary alcoholic beverage license. 
L.  Care of Facilities. Persons reserving city facilities shall be completely responsible for cleaning up the facilities after the event to the satisfaction of the director of community services or designee thereof. All reserved areas shall be left in a clean condition, with refuse placed in containers provided for such purpose. Failure to leave facility in clean condition will result in forfeiture of security deposit. Any organization or corporation reserving any area in a city park shall agree to assume full responsibility for all damage to city property by any invitee of such organization or corporation and shall make full payment therefore upon billing by the city administrator. Failure to do so shall deny future use of park facilities until such payment be made, in addition to any other remedy which the city may have. 
(Prior Code, § 12-1-5; Code 1998, § 12.24.050; Ord. No. 385, § 1(part), 2003) 
Sec. 12.24.060. - Foot bridge over Fox River at Webster Avenue. 
A.  Use Restricted. No person shall stand or loiter on the walkway or footbridge in any manner as to impede the regular flow of pedestrian traffic or to gather on the walkway or footbridge in any manner that may be construed as a public nuisance. No fishing is allowed off of any portion of the footbridge at any time. 
B.  Vehicles Prohibited. No person shall operate a bicycle, sled, snowmobile, motorcycle or any other motor vehicle, except those motorized vehicles specifically designed for the use of a handicapped person, over, upon or across the walkway or footbridge over the Fox River. Motorized vehicles specifically designed for the transport of a handicapped person shall be allowed. 
C.  Use of Abutments Prohibited. No person shall stand upon, loiter or walk upon any abutment or railing appertaining to the walkway or footbridge over the Fox River. 
D.  Preservation of Good Order. Any police officer may give an order for the preservation of good order and the equal convenience of the public on or near the walkway or footbridge over the Fox River, and any person refusing or neglecting to obey such order shall be subject to immediate arrest and to the penalty provided in Chapter 1.24. 
(Prior Code, § 12-1-6; Code 1998, § 12.24.060; Ord. No. 385, § 1(part), 2003) 
CHAPTER 12.26. - WATERWAYS; BOATS AND WATER SAFETY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Navigable waters, harbors and navigation, Wis. Stats. ch. 30; boating, Wis. Stats. § 30.50 et seq. 

Sec. 12.26.010. - Purpose and definition. 
A.  Purpose. It is hereby declared that it is in the best interest of the visual aesthetics, public health, safety or welfare, including the public's interest in preserving the state's natural resources, to enact an ordinance regulating boats and water safety on the waters within the jurisdiction of the City of Omro and the abatement of public nuisances arising from such. 
B.  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
1.  Abandoned boat means any boat left unattended and/or dilapidated on any and all waters within the legal boundary limits of the city for more than 21 consecutive days. 
2.  Boat means every description of watercraft used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on the water, except a seaplane or a fishing raft. 
3.  Boat house means a structure designed exclusively for the storage of boats which do not contain any furniture and furnishings and which is not at any time used for human habitation and which is anchored or fixed to any of the shorelines within the limits of the city. 
4.  Dilapidated means in disrepair, unseaworthy, partly ruined or decayed, especially as a result of neglect or maintenance. 
5.  House boat means a structure designed and arranged to be used for human occupancy or habitation which is without propulsion of any kind or which is anchored or fixed to any of the shorelines within the limits of the city. 
6.  Navigable means passable by ship or boat, especially deep enough and wide enough to allow ships or boats to sail through. 
7.  Navigable water means any waters within the territorial limits of the City of Omro.
