The permits referred to in this section shall only be granted upon application by a licensed and bonded plumber authorized by the agent or owner of the premises desiring to make such connection, extension, or alteration. The applicant shall state the name of the owner and that the applicant and owner will be bound by, and subject to, the rules and regulations prescribed in this chapter, Chapter 13.08, and any other applicable municipal or state regulation. Applications under this section shall give the exact location of the premises, the purpose of the connection, the time the work is to be done, and all other particulars reasonably required by the director of public works or designee, in relation thereto. 
B.  Penalties. This section ordains that the failure to connect to the municipal water system is contrary to the minimum health standards of the city and fails to ensure preservation of public health, comfort, and safety of the city residents. 
1.  Upon failure to do so, the city may cause such connection to be made and bill the property owner for such costs. If such costs are not paid within 30 days, such costs shall be assessed as a special tax lien against the property. However, the owner may, within 30 days after the completion of the work, file a written option with the city stating that he/she cannot pay such amount in one lump sum and ask that the amount be levied in portions not to exceed ten equal annual installments and that the amount shall be so collected with interest at the rate of eight percent per annum from the completion of the work, the unpaid balance being a special tax lien, all pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 281.45. 
2.  In lieu of the above, the city council, at its option, may: 
a.  Impose a penalty for the period that the violation continues, after ten days' written notice to any owner failing to make a connection to the municipal water system, an amount not less than $10.00 nor greater than $1,000.00 for the period in which the failure to connect continues, and upon failure to make such payment, such charge shall be assessed as a special tax lien against the property, all pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 281.45; 
b.  Commence court action to require connection to the municipal water system and to impose such other penalty as this section provides. 
(Code 1998, § 13.04.335; Ord. No. 441, 2-16-2010) 
Sec. 13.04.280. - Private well abandonment. 
A.  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to prevent contamination of groundwater and to protect public health, safety and welfare by ensuring that unused, unsafe or noncomplying wells, or wells which may serve as conduits for contamination, or wells which may be illegally cross-connected to the municipal water system, are properly abandoned. 
B.  Applicability. This section applies to all wells located on premises served by the city municipal water system. 
C.  Definitions. 
1.  Municipal water system means a system for the provision to the public of piped water for human consumption when such system has at least 15 service connections or regularly serves at least 25 yearround residents owned or operated by a city, village, county, town, town sanitary district, utility district or public institution or a privately owned water utility serving any of the above. 
2.  Noncomplying means a well or pump installation which does not comply with the provisions of applicable state rules in effect at the time the well was constructed, a contamination source was installed, the pump was installed, or work was done on either the well or pump installation. 
3.  Pump installation means the pump and related equipment used for withdrawing water from a well including the discharge piping, the underground connections, pitless adapters, pressure tanks, pits, sampling faucets and well seals or caps. 
4.  Unsafe means a well or pump installation which produces water which is bacteriologically contaminated or contaminated with substances in exceedance of the standards of Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 109 or 140, or for which a Health Advisory has been issued by the Department of Natural Resources. 
5.  Unused means a well or pump installation which is not in use or does not have a functional pumping system. 
6.  Well means an excavation or opening into the ground made by digging, boring, drilling, driving, or other methods for the purpose of obtaining groundwater for consumption or other use. 
7.  Well abandonment means the filling and sealing of a well according to state rules. 
D.  Abandonment Required. All wells located on premises served by the municipal water system shall be abandoned in accordance with the terms of this section and state rules, by no later than one year from the date of connection to the municipal water system, whichever occurs last, unless a well operation permit has been obtained by the well owner from the city. 
E.  Well Operation Permit. The city may grant a permit to a private well owner to operate a well for a period not to exceed five years providing the conditions of this section are met. An owner may request renewal of a well operation permit by submitting information verifying that the conditions of this section are met. The city or its agent may conduct inspections or have water quality tests conducted at the applicant's expense to obtain or verify information necessary for consideration of a permit application or renewal. Permit applications and renewals shall be made on forms provided by the city. The following conditions must be met for issuance or renewal of a well operation permit: 
1.  The well and pump installation meet or are upgraded to meet the requirements of state rules; 
2.  The well construction and pump installation have a history of producing bacteriologically safe water as evidenced by at least two samplings taken a minimum of two weeks apart. No exception to this condition may be made for unsafe wells, unless the Department of Natural Resources approves, in writing, the continued use of the well; 
3.  There are no cross connections between the well and pump installation and the municipal water system; 
4.  The proposed use of the well and pump installation can be justified as being necessary in addition to water provided by the municipal water system. 
F.  Abandonment Procedures. 
1.  All wells abandoned under the jurisdiction of this section or rule shall be abandoned according to the procedures and method in state rules. All debris, pump, piping, unsealed liners and any other obstructions which may interfere with sealing operations shall be removed prior to abandonment. 
2.  The owner of the well, or the owner's agent, shall notify the city at least 48 hours prior to commencement of any well abandonment activities. The abandonment of the well shall be observed by a representative of the city. 
3.  An abandonment report form, supplied by the Department of Natural Resources, shall be submitted by the well owner to the city and the Department of Natural Resources within ten days of the completion of the well abandonment. 
G.  Penalties. Any well owner violating any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by forfeiture of not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00 and the cost of prosecution. Each day of violation is a separate offense. If any person fails to comply with this section for more than ten days after receiving written notice of the violation, the municipality may impose a penalty and cause the well abandonment to be performed and the expense to be assessed as a special tax against the property. 
(Prior Code, § 9-1-53; Code 1998, § 13.04.340) 
CHAPTER 13.08. - SEWER USE AND SERVICE SYSTEM[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal utilities, Wis. Stats. § 66.0801 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 13.08.010. - Introduction and general provisions. 
A.  This chapter regulates the use of private sewers and drains and the discharge of waters and wastes into the public sewerage system of and within the City of Omro. This chapter provides for and explains the method used for levying and collecting wastewater treatment service charges, sets uniform requirements for discharges into the wastewater collection system, and enables the city to comply with administrative provisions, water quality requirements, toxic and effluent standards, and other discharge criteria, which are required or authorized by the State of Wisconsin or federal law. 
B.  The intent of this chapter is to derive the maximum public benefit by regulating the characteristics of wastewater discharged into the wastewater collection system. 
C.  This chapter provides a means for determining wastewater volumes, constituents and characteristics, the setting of charges and fees, and the issuing of permits to certain users. Revenues derived from the application of this chapter shall be used to defray the city's costs of operating and maintaining the wastewater treatment and collection system and to provide sufficient funds to pay for wastewater treatment, to pay for debt service costs, and to pay for equipment replacement costs. The charges and fees herein have been established pursuant to requirements of the Wisconsin Statutes. This chapter shall supersede any previous city ordinance, rules, or regulations; and shall repeal all parts thereof that may be inconsistent with this chapter. 
(Code 1998, § 13.08.010; Ord. No. 421(part), 2006) 
Sec. 13.08.020. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this chapter shall be as follows: 
1.  Approving authority means the city council of the City of Omro or its duly authorized committee, agent or representative. 
2.  Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD 5 ) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed as milligrams per liter. Quantitative determination of BOD 5 shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the most recent edition of Standard Methods." 
3.  Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a building drainage system that receives the discharge of wastewater and grey water from other drainage pipes inside the building and conveys the wastewater and grey water to the building service lateral. 
4.  Building service lateral sewer means the sanitary sewer piping from the public sanitary sewer or other place of disposal extending to the connection with the building drain at or near the exterior of the building wall. 
5.  Chlorine requirements means the amount of chlorine, in mg/l, which must be added to sewage to produce specified residual chlorine content in accordance with procedures set forth in "Standard Methods." 
6.  City means the City of Omro. 
7.  Compatible pollutants means biochemical oxygen demand (BOD 5 ), suspended solids, phosphorus, or pH levels that are generally treatable to a high degree, plus additional pollutants identified in the WPDES permit for the publicly owned treatment works receiving the pollutants, if such works were designed to treat such additional pollutants to a substantial degree, and in compliance with the City of Omro WPDES permit. 
8.  Debt service charges means and includes all costs associated with repayment of debts incurred for the construction and/or rehabilitation of the wastewater collection system and treatment facility. 
9.  Easement means an acquired legal right for the specified use of land owned by others. 
10.  Floatable oil means oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. Wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the sanitary sewer system. 
11.  Garbage means the residue from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage, and sale of food products and produce. 
12.  Ground garbage means the residue from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such degree that all particles will be no greater than one-half inch in any dimension and will be carried freely in suspension under normal flow conditions in a sanitary sewer. 
13.  Incompatible pollutants means wastewater or septage with pollutants that will adversely affect or disrupt the wastewater treatment processes or effluent quality or sludge quality if discharged to a wastewater treatment facility. 
14.  Industrial waste means the wastewater from an industrial process, trade, or business, including cooling water and the discharge from wastewater pretreatment facilities. Industrial wastewater is distinct and different from sanitary wastewater. 
15.  Licensed discharger means a person holding a license under Wis. Stats. § 281.41(3)(a). 
16.  Milligrams per liter shall be a weight-to-weight ratio; the milligrams per liter value multiplied by the factor 8.34 shall be equivalent to pounds per million gallons of water. Milligrams per liter is equivalent to parts per million. 
17.  Municipal wastewater means the spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences and commercial businesses and any groundwater, surface water, and stormwater that may be present. 
18.  Natural outlet means any outlet, including storm sewers, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
19.  Normal domestic strength wastewater means wastewater with concentrations less than 250 mg/l BOD 5 , 250 mg/l suspended solids, ten mg/l phosphorus, and 25 mg/l ammonia-nitrogen. 
20.  Normal user means a user whose contributions to the wastewater treatment facility consist only of normal domestic-strength waste originating from a house, apartment, condominium, or other living quarters occupied by a person or persons constituting a distinct household, business or commercial enterprise. 
21.  Operation and maintenance costs means and includes all costs associated with the operation and maintenance of the wastewater collection and treatment facilities. These costs, including costs associated with extraneous (clear water) flows, shall be divided equitably among the various sewer users. 
22.  Person means all persons, including any individual, firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association, society, institution, enterprise, government agency, or other entity. 
23.  pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration. The concentration is the weight of hydrogen ions, in grams per liter of solution. Neutral water, for example, has a pH value of seven and a hydrogen ion concentration of 10 -7 . 
24.  Private sewer lateral or sewer lateral means the portion of the sewer lateral between the right-of-way and the private home or other building provided sewer service and which sewer lateral is installed and maintained by the private property owner. 
25.  Public sewer means any sanitary sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the city. It shall also include sewers within or outside the city boundaries that serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge into the wastewater collection system, even though those sewers may not have been constructed with city funds. 
26.  Replacement costs means and includes all costs associated with establishing a fund to accumulate the necessary resources to replace equipment as required to maintain capacity and performance during the design life of the facility. 
27.  Sanitary sewage means "sanitary wastewater" or "wastewater," which is the preferred term. 
28.  Sanitary sewer means the same as a "public sewer," and either term may be used interchangeably. 
29.  Sanitary wastewater means "wastewater," which is the preferred term. 
30.  Septage means scum, liquid, sludge or other waste from a septic tank, soil absorption field, holding tank, vault toilet or privy. This does not include the waste from a grease trap. 
31.  Sewage means "sanitary wastewater" or "wastewater," which is the preferred term. 
32.  Sewer means a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater and drainage water. 
33.  Sewer service area means the area presently served or anticipated to be served by a wastewater collection system. 
34.  Sewer service charge means a service charge levied on users of the wastewater collection and treatment facilities for payment of capital expenses as well as operation and maintenance costs, including replacement of such facilities. 
35.  Sewer system and sanitary sewer system are interchangeable terms. Sewer system means the common sanitary sewers within a sewerage system, which are primarily installed to receive wastewater directly from facilities, which convey wastewater from individual structures or from private property, and which include service connection "Y" fittings designed for connection with those facilities. The facilities which convey wastewater from individual structures, from private property to the public sanitary sewer, or its equivalent, are specifically excluded from the definition of "sanitary sewer system," except that pumping units and pressurized lines for individual structures or groups of structures may be included as part of a "sewer system" when such units are cost-effective and are owned and maintained by the sanitary sewer system owner. 
36.  Wastewater facilities means the structures, equipment and processes required to collect, carry away and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent. 
37.  Wastewater treatment works means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge, sometimes used as synonymous with waste treatment. In the case of the city, the treatment works is for the treatment of all wastewater generated within the city or any portion of its sewer service area lying outside the corporate limits of the city. 
38.  Watercourse means a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water, either continuously or intermittently. 
39.  Wisconsin pollutant discharge elimination system (WPDES) permit means a document issued by the Wisconsin State Department of Natural Resources, which establishes effluent limitations and monitoring requirements for the municipal wastewater treatment facility. WPDES Permit No. WI-0025011 and modifications thereof pertains to the wastewater treatment facility in the city. 
(Code 1998, § 13.08.020; Ord. No. 421(part), 2006) 
Sec. 13.08.030. - Management, operation and control. 
A.  Management. The management, operation, and control of the wastewater treatment and collection system for the city is vested in the city council; all records, minutes and all written proceedings thereof shall be kept by the city clerk. 
B.  Construction. The city council shall have the power to construct sewer lines for public use, and shall have the power to lay sewer pipes in and through the alleys, streets, and public grounds of the city; and generally, to do all such work as may be found necessary or convenient in the management of the wastewater system. The city council shall have power by themselves, their officers, agents, and servants, to enter upon any land for the purpose of making examination or supervise in the performance of their duties under this chapter, without liability therefore; and the city council shall have power to purchase and acquire all real and personal property which may be necessary for construction of the sewer system, or for any repair, remodeling, or additions thereto. 
C.  Maintenance of Services. The individual property owner shall maintain sewer service for the private lateral from the main sewer line to the building receiving service including all controls between the same, without expense to the city, except when they are damaged because of negligence or carelessness on the part of the city. All private lateral sewer services must be maintained free of defective conditions, by and at the expense of the owner or occupant of the property. When any sewer service is to be relayed and there are two or more buildings on such service, each building shall be disconnected from such service and a new sewer service shall be installed for each building. The city shall maintain sewer service of all sewer mains, except when they are damaged because of negligence or carelessness on the part of the property owner. 
D.  Condemnation of Real Estate. Whenever any real estate or any easement therein, or use thereof, shall in the judgment of the city council be necessary to the sewer system, and whenever, for any cause, an agreement for the purchase thereof cannot be made with the owner thereof, the city council shall proceed with all necessary steps to obtain such real estate easement including condemnation in accordance with the Wisconsin Statutes and the Uniform Relocation and Real Property Acquisition Policy Act of 1970, if federal funds are used. 
E.  Title to Real Estate and Personal Property. All property, real, personal, and mixed, acquired for the construction of the sewer system, and all plans, specifications, diagrams, papers, books and records connected therewith such sewer system, and all buildings, machinery, and fixtures pertaining thereto, shall be the property of the city. 
(Code 1998, § 13.08.030; Ord. No. 421(part), 2006) 
Sec. 13.08.040. - User rules and regulations. 
A.  General. The rules, regulations, and sewer rates of the City of Omro hereinafter set forth shall be considered a part of the contract with every person, company or corporation who is connected to or uses the wastewater collection system and every such person, company or corporation by connecting with the wastewater collection system shall be considered as expressing their assent to be bound thereby. Whenever any of the rules and regulations, or such others as the city may hereafter adopt, are violated, the use of service shall be shut off from the building or place of such violation (even though two or more parties are receiving service through the same connection) and shall not be re-established except by order of the city council and on payment of all arrears, the expenses and established charges of shutting off and putting on, and such other terms as the city council may determine, and a satisfactory understanding with the party that no further cause for complaint shall arise. In case of such violation, the city council may declare any payment made for the service by the party or parties committing such violation to be forfeited, and the same shall thereupon be forfeited. The right is reserved by the city council to change the said rules, regulations, and wastewater rates from time to time, as they may deem advisable; and to make special rates and contracts in all proper cases. 
B.  Rules and Regulations. The following rules and regulations for the government of licensed plumbers, sewer users and others are adopted and established: 
1.  Plumbers. No plumber, pipefitter, or other person will be permitted to do any plumbing or pipefitting work in connection with the sewer system without first receiving a license from the State of Wisconsin and obtaining permission from the city. All service connections to the wastewater collection system shall comply with State Plumbing Code. 
2.  User's Mandatory Hook-Up. The owner of each parcel of land within the city adjacent to a sewer main on which there exists a building usable for human occupation, or in a block through which such system is extended, shall connect to such system within one year of notice in writing from the city of the availability of the sewer system for hookup. Upon failure to do so, the city may cause such connection to be made and bill the property owner for such costs. If such costs are not paid within 30 days, such costs shall be assessed as a special tax lien against the property. However, the owner may, within 30 days after the completion of the work, file a written option with the city stating that he/she cannot pay such amount in one sum and ask that it be levied in up to five equal annual installments, and the amount shall be so collected with interest at a rate not to exceed prime plus one percent from the date of the final resolution or the date of finalizing assessable costs, whichever is later. The unpaid balance shall be a special tax lien, all pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 281.45. 
3.  In Lieu of Above. In lieu of the above, the city council, at its option, may: 
a.  Impose a penalty for the period that the violation continues, after ten days written notice to any owner failing to make a connection to the wastewater collection system of an amount equal to 150 percent of the minimum quarterly charge for the sewer service payable monthly for the period in which the failure to connect continues, and upon failure to make such payment, such charge shall be assessed as a special tax lien against the property, all pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 281.45; 
b.  Commence court action to require connection to the wastewater collection system and to impose such other penalty as this section provides; 
c.  This section ordains that the failure to connect to the wastewater collection system is contrary to the minimum health standards of the city and fails to ensure preservation of public health, comfort, and safety of the city residents; 
d.  At the time of hook-up to the wastewater collection system, the private property owner shall also install a water meter provided by the city. This is required to enable monitoring and recording the water usage at each building for use in determining the quarterly user charge; 
e.  The owner of a property may elect to install a deduct water meter for water used for lawn watering purposes, thereby not incurring a sewer user charge for water used for lawn watering. Any meter proposed to be installed must be approved by the city in writing, installed by the property owner at his/her cost, and properly maintained by the property owner. 
C.  Private Systems Prohibited. The maintenance and use of septic tanks and other private wastewater disposal systems, including privies, outhouses, and other sanitary service, within the area of the city serviced by its sewer system are declared to be a public nuisance and a health hazard. The use of septic tanks or any private wastewater disposal system within the area serviced by the wastewater collection system shall be prohibited. 
D.  Application for Sewer Service. Every person connecting to the wastewater collection system shall file an application in writing to the city council in such form as is prescribed for that purpose and shall pay the application fee as required by the city. Blanks for such applications will be furnished at the office of the city clerk. The application must state fully and truly all the uses that will be allowed except upon further application and permission from the city council. If the applicant is not the owner of the premises, the written consent of the owner must accompany the application. Persons connected to the wastewater collection system of the city are referred to herein as "users." 
1.  If it appears that the service applied for will not provide adequate service for the contemplated use, the city council may reject the application. If the city council approves the application, it shall issue a permit for services as shown on the application. 
E.  Lateral Costs. Persons attaching to a public sewer main shall have the private lateral from the sewer main to the private building desiring service shall be installed at his/her own expense. 
F.  Tap Permits. After sewer connections have been introduced into any building or upon any premises, no plumber shall make any alterations, extensions, or attachments, unless the party ordering such tapping or other work exhibits the proper permit for the same from the city clerk. 
G.  User to Keep in Repair. All users shall keep their own service pipes in good repair and protected from frost, at their own risk and expense, and shall prevent any clearwater flow and unnecessary overburdening of the sewer system. The service pipe shall be defined to be the building drain and building sewer pipe extending from the interior drain of the building to the sewer main. All repairs shall be performed by a licensed plumber qualified to perform these services and all repairs shall comply with accepted plumbing practice. It shall be the responsibility of the user, in the event of a sewer lateral problem, to investigate the problem at its own expense and complete sewer repair as needed. In the event that the problem is due to the city sewer, the user shall notify the city. 
H.  Backflow Preventor. All sewer service laterals for new connections shall have a backflow prevention valve installed at the owner's expense, if required by the city council. 
I.  User Use Only. No user shall allow others or other services to connect to the wastewater collection system through his/her lateral, unless such connection is approved by the city council and is performed per the requirements of the city. 
J.  Vacating of Premises and Discontinuance of Service. Whenever premises served by the wastewater collection system are to be vacated, or whenever any person desires to discontinue service from the wastewater collection system, the city clerk must be notified in writing at least seven days before discontinuing service, or in the event of a fire or other event causing discontinuance of service, such discontinuance shall be notified to the city and service discontinued within seven days of occurring. The private lateral shall be capped and sealed at the point of the private building lateral connection with the city's sewer, to be watertight and to preclude any wastewater, surface water, or debris from entering the wastewater collection system. All costs and fees for inspection of the capping and sealing of the building sewer shall be borne by the property owner. 
K.  User to Permit Inspection. Every user shall permit the city or its duly authorized agent, at all reasonable hours of the day, to enter their premises or building to examine the pipes and fixtures, and the manner in which the drains and sewer connections operate. 
1.  No work shall be commenced without prior notification to the city at the time that the work will be done; this includes any cap and seal work or lateral installation. A representative of the city shall be present to inspect the work as it is being performed. 
L.  Utility Responsibility. It is expressly stipulated that no claim shall be made against the city or acting representative by reason of the breaking, clogging, stoppage, or freezing of any service pipes; nor from any damage arising from repairing mains, making connections or extensions or any other work that may be deemed necessary. The right is reserved to cut off the service at any time for the purpose of repairs or any other necessary purpose, any permit granted or regulations to the contrary notwithstanding. Whenever it shall become necessary to shut off the sewer within any portion of the city or its sewer service area, the city clerk shall, if practical, give notice to each consumer within the city or its sewer service area, of the time when such service will be shut off. 
M.  Excavations. In making excavations in streets or highways for laying service pipe or making repairs, the paving and the earth moved must be deposited in a manner that will occasion the least inconvenience to the public. Prior to excavation or work in the public right-of-way, notification and permits if required must be obtained from the city. 
1.  No person shall leave any such excavation made in any street or highway open at any time without barricades; and during the night, warning lights must be maintained at such excavations. All work in the public roadways must be performed subject to the approval of and under the requirements of the city. 
2.  In backfilling the opening, after the service pipes are laid, the earth must be laid in layers of not more than nine inches in depth, and each layer thoroughly compacted to prevent settling. This work, together with the replacing of sidewalks, gravel, and paving, must be done to make the street, at a minimum, as good as before it was disturbed, and satisfactory to the city. 
N.  Tapping the Mains. No person, except those having special permission from the city council or persons in their service and approved by them, will be permitted, under any circumstances, to tap the mains or collection pipes. The kind and size of the connection shall be that specified in the permits or order from the city council to ensure that new sewers and connections to the wastewater collection system are properly designed and constructed. 
1.  Pipes should always be tapped on a 45-degree angle from a horizontal plane, and not within six inches (15 centimeters) of the joint, or within 24 inches (60 centimeters) of another lateral connection. All service connections to mains must comply with state plumbing code. Service connections to an existing sewer main shall be made by means of a saddled wye or specially adapted tee. 
O.  Installation of Private Laterals. All service pipes (laterals) on private property will be installed in accordance with Wis. Admin. Code ch. SPS 382 "Design, Construction, Installation, Supervision and Inspection of Plumbing." All private laterals shall, as a minimum, be Schedule 40 PVC pipe. 
1.  All laterals will be inspected. The building sewer and/or private interceptor main sewer shall be inspected upon completion of placement of the pipe and before backfilling and tested before or after backfilling. The applicant for a lateral connection permit shall notify the city when the private lateral is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer and the lateral shall be inspected by the city prior to backfilling. 
P.  Extensions. The city shall extend sewer mains in accordance with the following charges and the following conditions: 
1.  When an extension main is desired by a prospective user, such person shall make an application for such an extension in writing to the city council by filing a written application for the same with the city clerk. After the filing of such an application, the city engineer shall first consider the feasibility of the additional service extension with respect to the available treatment capacity. If extension appears feasible, then the city engineer shall determine the location of the next manhole or manholes, or the means by which service may be extended. Next, the city engineer shall design the extension, taking into consideration the prospective demands for service, the capacity of downstream facilities, and the orderly development of the particular area and obtain all local and state approvals. No extension shall be made for a distance less than to the next manhole. All sewer extensions shall be constructed in compliance with local and state laws, ordinances, and regulations. 
2.  The person who requests the extension shall pay the entire cost of such extension including the manhole or manholes that are part of the extension. If more than one user is involved, the entire cost shall be divided among these users, as they mutually agree to. The assessment of cost and method of payment may be established by the city council in a manner similar to that established for the initial sewer project. 
Q.  Additional Authority. The city has established a specific connection charge for any connection to the wastewater collection system beyond the initial construction. It is further provided that the city may amend or alter any connection charge after its establishment under the terms of this section or previous ordinance or resolution. 
R.  State of Wisconsin Statutes and Administrative Code Provisions. In addition to the provisions provided in this section, all applicable State of Wisconsin Statutes and Wisconsin Administrative Code Provisions shall apply. The city has the authority to enforce any such statute or code. If there is a conflict between this section and state statutes or the administrative code, the most restrictive requirements shall govern. 
(Code 1998, § 13.08.040; Ord. No. 421(part), 2006) 
Sec. 13.08.050. - Use of the public sewerage system. 
A.  Prohibitions Against Discharge. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described liquids or solid wastes to any sanitary sewer or wastewater treatment facility: 
1.  Any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof run-off, sump pumps, or surface drainage or any other connections from inflow sources to the wastewater collection sewer. Such waters may be discharged to a storm sewer or other waterway with permission of the city. 
2.  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, lubricating oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas, or other substances which by themselves or by interaction with other substances may cause fire or explosion hazards, or in any other way be injurious to persons, property, or the operation of the wastewater facilities. 
3.  Any waters or waste containing toxic or poisonous substances in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, which will injure or interfere with any wastewater treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment facility, or interfere with the disposal of sludge. 
4.  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than five or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel or the wastewater treatment facility. 
5.  Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of ten. 
6.  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the wastewater facilities such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, rocks, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair or fleshings, entrails, and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
7.  Wastewater having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit or that causes the wastewater at the treatment facility to exceed 104 degrees Fahrenheit. 
8.  Any water or wastes which may contain more than 100 parts per million by weight of oils, fat or grease. Furthermore, all restaurants are required to install and maintain grease interceptors in accordance with the Wisconsin Plumbing Code. 
9.  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. Garbage grinders may be connected to sanitary sewers from homes, hotels, institutions, restaurants, hospitals, catering establishments, or similar places where garbage originates from the preparation of food in kitchens for the purpose of consumption on the premises or when served by caterers. 
10.  Any waters or waste containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, mercury, and similar objectionable or toxic substances to such degree that any such material received in the composite wastewater at the treatment facility exceeds the limits that may be established by the city for such materials. 
11.  Any waters or wastes containing odor-producing substances exceeding limits, which may be established by the city. 
12.  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the city in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
13.  Quantities of flow, concentrations, or both which constitute a slug load. 
14.  Incompatible pollutants containing substances, which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the wastewater treatment processes, employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the wastewater treatment facility effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
15.  Any water or wastes which, by interaction with other water or wastes in the public sewer system, release obnoxious gases, form suspended solids which interfere with the collection system, or create a condition deleterious to structures and treatment processes. 
16.  Materials, which exert or cause: 
a.  Unusually high BOD 5 , chemical oxygen demand or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the wastewater treatment facility; 
b.  Unusual flow or concentrated wastes constituting a slug load; 
c.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, fuller's earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium sulfate); 
d.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions). 
B.  Septage Disposal. No person or licensed disposer shall dispose of septage (holding tank or septic tank waste) into any sewer manhole located within the city. 
C.  Special Agreements. No statement contained in this section shall be construed as prohibiting any special agreement between the city and any person whereby a residential or commercial waste of unusual strength or character may be admitted to the wastewater collection system, either before or after pretreatment, provided that there is no impairment of the functioning of the collection system or subsequent wastewater treatment by reason of the admission of such wastes and no extra costs are incurred by the city. 
D.  Permit Required. It is unlawful to discharge to any natural waterway within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any wastewater or other polluted waters, without first obtaining a Wisconsin pollutant discharge elimination system (WPDES) permit. 
E.  Fines for Prohibited Discharges. If any prohibited discharge shall occur and result in an increased loading, inhibit treatment, or result in exceeding the treatment system discharge permit, the responsible person or party causing such discharge shall be responsible for all costs incurred by the city. Prohibited discharges shall be subject to a minimum fine of $100.00 per day as determined by the city for each calendar day the prohibited discharge occurs. 
F.  Clear Water Prohibited. No person shall connect any roof drain, cistern overflow, sump pump, area drain, surface drain, cooling waterline, or any other type of drainline that would allow surface water, groundwater, rainwater, or any other type of unpolluted water to enter the wastewater collection system. Existing prohibited clear water connections must be removed from the building sewer before connection to the wastewater collection system. Any person in violation of this requirement shall be subject to immediate imposition of a fine as set forth in this section and shall disconnect all sources of clear water from the wastewater collection sewer system within 30 days from the date of written notice by the city. If any person fails to comply after the expiration of the time provided, the city may cause disconnection to be made and charge the costs thereof as a special charge against the property. The costs of disconnection shall be charged in addition to any fines imposed for violation of this section. A fine of $100.00 per day shall be imposed upon any person in violation of this section. All costs of prosecution shall be added to all fines imposed. 
(Code 1998, § 13.08.050; Ord. No. 421(part), 2006) 
Sec. 13.08.060. - User charge system. 
A.  Policy. It shall be the policy of the city council to obtain sufficient revenues to pay the debt service costs and the costs of the operation, maintenance, and equipment replacement of the wastewater treatment and collection system through a system of sewer service charges as defined in this chapter. The system shall ensure that each user of the system pays a proportionate share of the cost of such facilities. 
B.  Assignment of Sewer Users. The city will assign sewer users into appropriate sewer service charge categories if wastewater sampling programs and other related information indicate a change of categories is necessary. 
C.  User Charge Methodology. The following methodology shall be used to calculate the debt service and operation, maintenance and repair (OM&R) charges for the collection and treatment of city wastewater: 
1.  Quarterly Fixed Charge. The quarterly fixed charge is a charge imposed upon all connections to the system. The fixed charge shall be established by the city and applied to all users. This cost is based entirely on meter size and is independent of wastewater flow. The fixed charge shall be applied to debt service with any remaining amounts applied to the operating costs of the city until such time that the city project financing is paid and the fixed charge can be deleted. 
2.  Quarterly Variable OM&R Charge. The quarterly variable OM&R charge shall be paid by all users based on the cost per 1,000 gallons of flow. The total annual costs are divided by the total annual loadings to obtain the unit cost per billing parameter. 
(Code 1998, § 13.08.060; Ord. No. 421(part), 2006) 
Sec. 13.08.070. - Septic tank and holding tank waste. 
A.  Septic Tanks and Holding Tanks Prohibited. The maintenance and use of septic tanks, holding tanks or other private disposal systems within the sewer service area of the city serviced by its wastewater collection system are declared a public nuisance and a health hazard. The use of these systems is prohibited unless a special permit is obtained from the city. Upon abandonment of the septic tank or holding tank, the tank shall be filled with sand or gravel in a manner acceptable to the city. 
B.  Septic Tank and Holding Tank Disposal. No person in the business of gathering and disposing of septic tank or holding tank wastes shall transfer such material into any disposal area or manhole located within the city boundaries unless a permit for disposal has been first obtained from the city. Written application for this permit shall be made to the city and shall state the name and address of the applicant; the number of its disposal units; and the make, model and license number of each unit. Permits shall be nontransferable except in case of replacement of the disposal unit for which a permit shall have been originally issued. The permit may be obtained upon payment of a fee. The city shall establish annual fees. Any applicant for a permit shall furnish a bond to the city in the amount of $5,000.00 to guarantee performance. The bond shall be provided prior to the permit being issued. The city will designate the time and place of disposal. The city may impose such conditions as it deems necessary on any permit granted. Bills shall be mailed on a monthly basis and if payments are not received in 30 days thereof, disposal privileges shall be suspended. 
1.  Any commercial hauler of septic tank or holding tank wastes agrees to carry public liability insurance in an amount not less than $100,000.00 and to protect all persons or property from injury and/or damage caused in any way or manner by any act, or failure to act, by any of his/her employees. A certificate certifying such insurance to be in full force and effect shall be furnished to the city. 
2.  Any wastes discharged into the wastewater treatment system shall be of domestic origin and will comply with the provisions of all applicable ordinances of the city. A discharger shall not deposit or drain any gasoline, oil, acid, alkali, grease, rags, waste, volatile, or inflammable liquids or other deleterious substances into any manhole nor allow any earth, sand or solid material to pass into any part of the wastewater system. 
3.  Any person or party disposing of septic tank or holding tank wastes agrees to indemnify and save harmless the City of Omro from all liability and claims for damage arising out of or resulting from work and labor performed. 
(Code 1998, § 13.08.070; Ord. No. 421(part), 2006) 
Sec. 13.08.080. - Industrial and septage wastes prohibited. 
A.  Industrial Discharges. The discharge of any waters or wastes, which waters, wastes, or septage contain substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in Section 13.08.050 which may have deleterious effects upon the wastewater treatment facility, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life, health, or constitute a public nuisance are prohibited to be discharged to the city sanitary sewer system. 
B.  Grease and/or Sand Interceptors. The city has the authority to require grease, oil, and sand interceptors when deemed necessary. Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided by the discharger and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. In the maintaining of these interceptors, the discharger shall be responsible for the proper removal and disposal of the captured material and shall maintain records of the dates and means of disposal, which are subject to review by the city. Properly licensed disposal firms must perform any removal and hauling of the collected materials not performed by the discharger's personnel. 
C.  Analyses. 
1.  All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of a wastewater to which reference is made in this section shall be determined in accordance with "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association and "Guidelines Establishing Test Procedures for Analysis of Pollutants," (1978, 40 CFR 136). Sampling methods, locations, times, durations, and frequencies are to be determined on an individual basis subject to approval by the city. 
2.  Determination of the character and concentration of wastewater shall be made by the person discharging them or his/her agent, as designated and required by the city. The city may also make its own analyses of the wastes and these determinations shall be used as a basis for charges. If the person discharging the waste contests the determination, the city may elect to have an independent laboratory determine the character and concentration of the waste. Such independent laboratory shall be acceptable to both the city and the person discharging the waste. The discharger shall assume all costs incurred by the independent laboratory in making the determination. 
D.  Submission of Information. Plans, specifications, and any other pertinent information relating to any proposed pretreatment, grease trap, or sand interceptor shall be submitted for review of the city prior to the start of construction if the effluent from such facilities is to be discharged into the public sewers. 
E.  Submission of Basic Data. Commercial users desiring to make a new connection to a public sewer for discharging wastes shall prepare and file with the city a report that shall include actual or predicted data relating to the quantity and characteristics of the waste to be discharged. 
F.  Time Schedule. For a new hook-up to the wastewater collection system which requires a grease trap or sand interceptor, such grease trap or sand interceptor shall be installed by the owner, and inspected and approved by the city prior to initiating wastewater flow to the city. 
1.  For an existing discharger, such grease trap or sand interceptor shall be installed by the owner, and inspected and approved by the city within 90 days of notification of such requirement. 
2.  When it can be demonstrated that circumstances exist which would create an unreasonable burden on the person proposing to discharge a waste, to comply with the time schedule imposed in this section, a request for extension of the time may be presented for consideration by the city council. 
G.  Cost. The city shall have the authority to install any pretreatment system if the owner does not comply with these requirements within 90 days of notification and charge the owner for all costs incurred or at its option place this cost as a lien on the owner's property taxes. 
(Code 1998, § 13.08.080; Ord. No. 421(part), 2006) 
Sec. 13.08.090. - Payment of charges. 
A.  Payment and Penalty. The sewer service charge shall be billed on a quarterly basis and shall be payable to the city not later than 40 days after the end of each period. A penalty of three percent but not less than $0.50 shall be added to all bills not paid by the date fixed for final payment. 
B.  Delinquent Charges. All delinquent wastewater charges shall be a lien upon the property pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0821(4) and shall be collected in the manner therein provided. 
C.  Disposition of Revenue. The amounts received from the collection of charges authorized by this section shall be credited to a sewer account, which shall show all receipts and expenditures of the system. Charges collected for replacement expenses shall be credited to a segregated, nonlapsing replacement account. These funds are to be used exclusively for replacement. When appropriated by the city, the credits to the sewer account shall be available for the payment of the requirements for operation, maintenance, repairs, and depreciation of the system consistent with Wis. Admin Code NR 162.11. Any surplus outside the purview of Wis. Admin Code NR 162.11, in such account, shall be available for the payment of principal and interest of bonds issued and outstanding, or which may be issued, to provide funds for the sanitary sewer system, or part thereof, and all or a part of the expenses for additions and improvements and other necessary disbursements or indebtedness, and the city may resolve to pledge each surplus or any part thereof for any such purpose. 
D.  Excess Revenues. Excess revenues collected for a user class will be applied to operation and maintenance costs or fixed costs attributable to that class for the next year. 
E.  Annual Audit. The city shall conduct an audit annually or as required by the applicable funding agency. The purpose of audit shall be to maintain the proportionality between the users and user classes of the user charge system and to ensure that adequate revenues are available relative to increasing operation, maintenance, and replacement costs. 
(Code 1998, § 13.08.090; Ord. No. 421(part), 2006) 
Sec. 13.08.100. - Violations and penalties. 
A.  Damages. No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure of pertinence or equipment, which is a part of the system. 
B.  Written Notice of Violation. Any person, partnership, corporation, or other business entity, or any officer, agent, or employee thereof, connected to the sanitary sewer system found to be violating a provision of this chapter shall be served by the city with a written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time not to exceed 30 calendar days for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violation. 
1.  Any licensed discharger discharging to a public sewer, found to be violating a provision of this chapter, may have their approval immediately revoked. This revocation shall be done in writing and state the reason for revoking the approval. 
C.  Accidental Discharge. Any person found to be responsible for accidentally allowing a deleterious discharge into the wastewater collection system, which causes damage to the city treatment facility, and/or receiving body of water shall, in addition to a fine, pay the amount to cover damages, both values to be established by the city. 
D.  Continued Violations. Any person, partnership, or corporation, or any officer, agent, or employee thereof, who shall continue any violation beyond the aforesaid notice time limit provided, shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $100.00 per day of continued violation and the cost of prosecution as determined by the city. In default of payment of such forfeiture and costs, the costs shall be placed on the property tax to obtain payment. Each day in which any violation is continued beyond the aforesaid notice time limit shall be deemed a separate offense. Nothing in this chapter shall preclude the city from maintaining an appropriate action to prevent or remove a violation of any provisions of this chapter. 
E.  Liability to City for Losses. Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned by reason of such violation, which the city may suffer as a result thereof. 
F.  Damage Recovery. The city shall have the right of recovery from all persons, any expense incurred by the system for the repair or replacement of any part of the system damaged in any manner by any person by the performance of any work under their control, or by any negligent acts. 
G.  Penalties. Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or rules or regulations of the city or who shall connect a service pipe or discharge without first having obtained a permit therefore; or who shall violate any provisions of the Wisconsin Statutes, Wisconsin Administrative Code, or any other requirements which are incorporated by reference, shall forfeit not less than $100.00 per day for each day a violation occurs and any costs of prosecution. This, however, shall not bar the city from enforcing the connection duties for mandatory hookup. Each day in which such violation continues, shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1998, § 13.08.100; Ord. No. 421(part), 2006) 
Secs. 13.08.110-13.08.140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LIMITATIONS ON CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 13.08.150. - Limitation on sewer and water connections outside of municipal boundaries. 
A.  City policy against providing sewer and water outside of municipal boundaries . The city's long standing policy is to provide city services, such as sewer and water, only to city residents and to encourage property owners located outside of the city to annex to the city in order to access city services. 
B.  Limitation on obligation to serve outside of municipal boundaries . This article shall limit the city's provision of wastewater and/or water service outside the city's municipal boundaries. The city shall have no obligation to serve any property outside the corporate limits of the city with wastewater and/or water except as provided in this article. This article shall constitute a limitation on the city's obligation to provide water and water services outside its municipal boundaries as allowed under Wis. Stats. § 66.0813(3). 
C.  Limited provision of wholesale wastewater treatment service to Algoma Sanitary District No. 1 . To the limited extent provided in article III of this chapter, the city will provide wastewater treatment service to Algoma Sanitary District No. 1. The city does not undertake to provide service to Algoma Sanitary District No. 1 beyond that provided by article III of this chapter. 
( Ord. No. 474, § 1, 8-2-2016 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 474 , § 1, adopted Aug. 2, 2016, set out provisions intended for use as § 13.10.010. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 13.08.150. 
Secs. 13.08.160-13.08.190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TERMS AND CONDITIONS APPLICABLE TO THE PROVISION OF WASTEWATER TREATMENT SERVICE TO ALGOMA SANITARY DISTRICT NO. 1[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 475 , § 2, adopted Sept. 20, 2016, set out provisions intended for use as §§ 13.11.010-13.11.090. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as Art. III, §§ 13.08.200-13.08.270. 

Sec. 13.08.200. - Wholesale wastewater treatment service to Algoma Sanitary District No. 1. 
A.  Eligibility for Wholesale Wastewater Treatment Service . To the limited extent provided in this article, Algoma Sanitary District No. 1 is authorized to discharge wastewater it collects in its wastewater collection system from eligible properties (as defined in this article) directly to the city's wastewater treatment facility. The city will, to the limited extent set forth in this article, accept for treatment the wastewater collected by Algoma Sanitary District No. 1 from eligible properties. 
B.  Definitions. 
1.  District means, for purposes of this article, Algoma Sanitary District No. 1 and its respective successors and assigns, or such other public boards, committees, commissions or entities as shall succeed substantially to the right, powers, and duties of the district. 
2.  Eligible property means a property which meets all the following requirements: 
a.  The property is located within the district's boundaries. 
b.  The property is located within the eligible service area. 
c.  The district has issued a permit authorizing the property to be connected to the district's wastewater collection system, and has forwarded a copy of that permit to the city within 30 days of authorization. 
d.  A plumber licensed by the State of Wisconsin has installed all connections of the property to the district's wastewater collection system. 
e.  The connections between the property and the district's wastewater collection system have been installed in accordance with all state and local regulations. 
f.  The connections between the property and the district's wastewater collection system have been inspected and approved by the district's plumbing inspector. 
g.  The district has provided the city with a copy of the district's inspection report prepared by the district's inspector verifying that the connections between the property and the district's wastewater collection system have been inspected and were made in accordance with all state and local regulations. 
h.  Each connection between the property and the district's wastewater collection system sewer has been installed within two years of sewer connection permit issuance. 
i.  The district has paid the city the applicable connection fee for the eligible property. 
j.  The wastewater generated from the property will not exceed normal domestic strength wastewater as defined by the city's code of ordinances. 
k.  The property has not lost its "eligible property" status for one of the reasons provided in section 13.08.250. 
3.  Eligible service area means, for purposes of this article, all lands lying within the district's boundaries and in the Omro Sewer Service Area as approved by the East Central Regional Planning Commission, except those lands lying within the area bounded by: 
South Line: County Road E; 
West Line: 2nd Avenue extending the boundary straight north along Broderick Road to Liberty School Road; 
North Line: Liberty School Road extending the boundary straight east to Rivermoor Road; and 
East Line: the western right-of-way line of Rivermoor Road south to Highway 21, east along Highway 21 to Scott Street, then straight south to County Road E. 
Notwithstanding the foregoing, the following specific parcels shall be included in the eligible service area: (i) all parcels located on Vande Street, Clark Street, and Cleve Street; (ii) parcels 016-0234-02 and 016-0234-03 located on Young's Road; (iii) the Omro Town Hall parcel located at 4205 Rivermoor Road consisting of a 1.11 acre parcel identified as parcel 016-0267; and (iv) the parcels located at 1717, 1739, 1748, 1762, 1780, 1936, 2104 and 2148 Springbrook Road and 1132 Willow Street, all of which were connected prior to October 31, 1997. 
C.  Service to Eligible Properties . The district is not authorized to deliver wastewater from a potentially eligible property to the city's wastewater treatment plant until the district provides the city a copy of the district's inspection report along with the connection fee due for the eligible property. 
D.  Limitation on Service . The city expressly declines to provide the district wastewater treatment service for the area excluded from the definition of eligible service area. The city is expressly reserving this excluded area for future annexation by the city. 
( Ord. No. 475 , § 2, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 13.08.210. - Volumetric discharge limit. 
    The district shall have no right to discharge to the city's wastewater treatment plant more than 607,760 gallons of wastewater per day averaged over a one-month period. 
( Ord. No. 475 , § 2, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 13.08.220. - Connection fees. 
A.  Amount of Connection Fee. The city shall charge the district a connection fee for each eligible property connected to the district's wastewater collection system. The connection fee charged to the district for an eligible property shall be the same as the connection fee charged for a similar property located within the city. The district shall be charged one connection fee for a single family residence and two or more connection fees for duplexes and larger structures. the amount of the city's connection fee per hook-up shall be as provided in a fee schedule approved by the Omro Common Council. 
B.  Failure to Pay a Violation. The district's failure to pay a connection fee for an eligible property is a violation of this article and could trigger fines and/or disconnection as provided in section 13.08.270. 
( Ord. No. 475 , § 2, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 13.08.230. - Wholesale wastewater treatment rates and charges; billing. 
A.  Rates Established by Common Council. The city will charge the district for wastewater treatment services as provided in this section. The rates charged to the district shall be established by the common council as shown in the city fee schedule, which may be amended from time to time. The city uses "cash basis" accounting that does not include depreciation expense in the revenue requirement. When establishing new rates, the rates will be computed using projected expenses for a forward looking test year (one year in the future), and flow data and equivalent meter data for the most recently completed year will be used. 
B.  Fixed Charge. The city shall charge the district a fixed charge to recover the district's share of the city's fixed asset costs (other than those fixed asset costs related to the city's wastewater collection system). 
1.  The city's fixed charge shall be comprised of debt service, debt service coverage at a rate of 1.25 times lending requirements, and equipment replacement funds. 
2.  The fixed asset costs do not change based on volume of wastewater conveyed to the treatment plant, therefore, the fixed charge is allocated to customers based on connections and meter equivalents. 
3.  The district's share of fixed asset costs, other than those fixed asset costs related to the city's wastewater collection system) is based on the number of connections to the District's system. 
4.  All fixed charges collected from the district shall be used for the equipment replacement fund, debt service or debt service reserves for capital improvements to the city's wastewater system (other than the city's collection system) or placed in a reserve, replacement or depreciation fund to be used for future capital improvements to the city's wastewater system (other than the city's collection system). 
C.  Wholesale Volume Charge. The city shall charge the district a wholesale volume charge equal to the district's volume of wastewater conveyed by the district to the city's wastewater treatment plant multiplied by the wholesale volumetric rate. The wholesale volumetric rate shall be set by the common council taking into account the city's operation and maintenance costs (other than those operation and maintenance costs related to the city's wastewater collection system), and the volume of all wastewater treated at the wastewater treatment plant. 
D.  Billing Dates and Payment Terms . The city will bill the District quarterly for services rendered. Invoices shall be due and paid in full within 40 days of the date of mailing. Payment received by the city after the due date will be subject to a three percent late payment charge. 
( Ord. No. 475 , § 2, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 13.08.240. - Measurement; reimbursement of costs. 
A.  Flow Measurement. The city will measure the volume of wastewater the district conveys to the city's wastewater treatment facility using a city owned meter located in a metering manhole on the city's wastewater treatment plant property. The city will periodically arrange for the testing and calibration of the flow meter equipment. These costs will be spread over all the ratepayers. 
( Ord. No. 475 , § 2, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 13.08.250. - Loss of eligible property status. 
A.  A property loses its eligible property status if it converts from a single family residential use to a multi-family or condominium use unless the district pays any additional connection fees owed as a result of the conversion. Any conversion to multi-family or condominium use that increases the number of residential equivalents on a property shall be subject to additional connection fees. 
B.  A property loses its eligible property status if it converts from an existing residential use to industrial or commercial use unless the district receives city common council approval for the conversion, and the district pays any additional connection fees owed as a result of the conversion. 
C.  A property loses its eligible property status if it discharges or will discharge wastewater that exceeds normal domestic strength wastewater unless the district receives city common council approval for the discharge of wastewater exceeding normal domestic strength waste from that property. 
( Ord. No. 475 , § 2, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 13.08.260. - Conditions for continued wastewater treatment service; prohibitions. 
A.  Conditions. The city's undertaking to provide wastewater treatment service to the district is conditioned on the district meeting and continuing to meet each one of the following conditions. 
1.  The district's wastewater collection system must be constructed, operated and maintained in compliance with federal and state requirements. 
2.  The district, as a user of the city's system, must comply with the city's sewer use ordinance. 
3.  The district must adopt, maintain and enforce a sewer use ordinance for its users which is substantially similar to the city's sewer use ordinance. 
4.  The wastewater discharged from the district's wastewater collection system to the city's wastewater treatment facility shall not exceed normal domestic strength wastewater as defined by the city's code of ordinances. 
5.  The district must adhere to and enforce all state and local regulations regarding separation and elimination of clearwater from sanitary wastes. 
6.  The district shall, at its expense, reduce infiltration/inflow into the district's wastewater collection system whenever such infiltration is in excess of any limits imposed or standards set by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources or the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
7.  The district is responsible for notifying the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources of a discharge to or from its wastewater system in violation of federal or state law, or its wastewater discharge permit. 
8.  The district is responsible for implementing a capacity, management, operation, and maintenance program for its own wastewater system that satisfies the requirements of Wis. Admin. Code NR 210.23. 
9.  The district shall immediately notify the city of any occurrence or situation that may adversely affect the wastewater treatment plant. 
10.  The district shall submit all plans for sewer main extensions, new lift stations or new force mains within the district to the city for the city's approval, which approval shall not be unreasonably denied. 
B.  Specific Prohibitions. Under no condition shall the district take the following actions. 
1.  The district shall not convey wastewater generated or collected from properties other than eligible properties to the city's wastewater treatment facility. 
2.  The district shall not convey wastewater generated from users outside of the eligible service area to the city's wastewater treatment facility. 
3.  The district shall not transmit wastewater generated from a property for which a connection charge has not been paid to the city as specified in section 13.08.220. 
4.  The district shall not transmit wastewater with greater than domestic strength waste to the city's wastewater treatment facility unless expressly approved by the common council. 
5.  The district shall not permit septic waste, seepage pit wastes, grease-trap wastes, lift station grease solids, or any trucked liquid wastes or wastewater from unconnected properties or from properties in the process of abandonment to be deposited in its wastewater collection system and conveyed to the city's wastewater treatment facility. 
( Ord. No. 475 , § 2, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 13.08.270. - Violations. 
    If it is determined by the city that the district has violated this article, the city shall notify the district of the violation in writing and shall require the district to exercise its best efforts to cease and desist such action immediately; and in the event the district fails to take corrective action (or in the alternate to satisfactorily assure the city that corrective action will be taken within a specified period of time), the city is authorized to proceed to enforce the article using the enforcement process applicable to wastewater discharges set forth in the city's code of ordinances at section 13.08.100. 
( Ord. No. 475 , § 2, 9-20-2016) 
CHAPTER 13.12. - UTILITIES 

Sec. 13.12.010. - Purpose. 
    It is the intention of the city to require all utilities to be buried underground wherever it is consistent with the law and existing development. 
(Code 1998, § 13.12.010; Ord. No. 401(part), 2005) 
Sec. 13.12.020. - Utilities in existing plats and for other areas of the City of Omro. 
    All telephone, utility, cable television and electrical cable hereafter installed outside of any city right-of-way and which are to serve any residential, commercial or industrial property in any areas of the city shall be buried underground. This requirement shall include feeder cables and individual service connections. The planning commission may waive this requirement for any of the following reasons: 
1.  The location, topography, soil, solid rock, boulders, or other physical conditions would make underground installation unreasonable or impractical; or 
2.  The lots to be served by the facilities can be served directly from existing overhead facilities. 
(Code 1998, § 13.12.020; Ord. No. 401(part), 2005) 
Sec. 13.12.030. - Utilities in municipal right-of-way. 
    The common council may elect to require telephone, utility, cable television and electrical cable located within municipal rights-of-way to be buried underground. In any case where the common council requires underground installation of utilities, the common council or a third party must agree to reimburse the utility for the difference in cost between the standard design or construction techniques of the utility and the cost of installation of utilities underground. Further, the underground installation must be consistent with safe and reliable utility construction. 
(Code 1998, § 13.12.030; Ord. No. 401(part), 2005)

CHAPTER 15.04. - BUILDING CODE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- One- and two-family dwelling code, Wis. Stats. § 101.60 et seq.; modular home code, Wis. Stats. § 101.70 et seq.; electrical wiring and electricians, Wis. Stats. § 101.80 et seq.; manufactured homes and mobile homes, Wis. Stats. § 101.91 et seq.; multifamily dwelling code, Wis. Stats. § 101.971 et seq.; elevators, escalators and other conveyances, Wis. Stats. § 101.981 et seq.; local authority relative to buildings and construction, Wis. Stats. §§ 101.65, 101.76, 101.86, 101.861, 101.975. 

ARTICLE 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 15.04.010. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the "Building Code of the City of Omro" and will be referred to in this chapter as "this chapter." 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-1(a); Code 1998, § 15.04.010; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.020. - Purpose. 
    This chapter provides certain minimum standards, provisions and requirements for safe and stable design, methods of construction and uses of materials in buildings and/or structures hereafter erected, constructed, enlarged, altered, repaired, moved, converted to other uses or demolished and regulates the equipment, maintenance, use and occupancy of all such buildings and/or structures. Its purpose is to protect and foster the health, safety and well-being of persons occupying or using such buildings and the general public. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-1(b); Code 1998, § 15.04.020; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.030. - Scope. 
    New buildings hereafter erected in, or any building hereafter moved within or into the city, shall conform to all the requirements of this chapter except as they are herein specifically exempted from part or all of its provisions. Any alteration, enlargement or demolition of an existing building and any installation therein of electrical, gas, plumbing, heating, air conditioning, ventilating or fire protection equipment which affects the health or safety of the users thereof or any other persons is a new building to the extent of such change. Any existing building shall be considered a new building for the purposes of this chapter whenever it is used for dwelling, commercial or industrial purposes, unless it was being used for such purpose at the time this chapter was enacted. The provisions of this chapter supplement by the current laws of the State of Wisconsin, pertaining to the construction and use, and which are adopted in their entirety, also included is the zoning code of the city and amendments thereto to the date this chapter was adopted and in no way supersede or nullify such law and the zoning code. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-1(c); Code 1998, § 15.04.030; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.040. - Fees. 
A.  Building Code Fees. The fees for building, electrical, plumbing, HVAC (heating, ventilation, and air conditioning) and other related permits shall be as listed on the schedule posted in the city clerk's office. 
B.  Triple Fees. If a required permit is not obtained prior to commencement of construction, fees shall be tripled. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-15; Code 1998, § 15.04.040; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.050. - Disclaimer on inspections. 
A.  The purpose of the inspections under this chapter is to improve the quality of housing in the city. The inspections and the reports and findings issued after the inspections are not intended as, nor are they to be construed as, a guarantee. 
B.  In order to so advise owners and other interested persons the following disclaimer shall be applicable to all inspections: 
These findings of inspection contained herein are intended to report conditions of noncompliance with code standards that are readily apparent at the time of inspection. The inspection does not involve a detailed examination of the mechanical systems or the closed structural and nonstructural elements of the building and premises. No warranty of the operation, use or durability of equipment and materials not specifically cited herein is expressed or implied. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-9; Code 1998, § 15.04.050; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.060. - Unsafe buildings. 
A.
