Whenever the building inspector or other authorized inspector, finds any building or part thereof within the city to be, in his/her judgment, so old, dilapidated, or out of repair as to be dangerous, unsafe, unsanitary or otherwise unfit for human occupancy or use and so that it would be unreasonable to repair the same, the building inspector may order the owner to raze and remove such building or part thereof or, if it can be made safe by repairs, to repair and make safe and sanitary, or to raze and remove at the owner's option. 
B.  The building inspector shall give specific reasons for his/her determination. Such order and proceedings shall be as provided in Wis. Stats. § 66.0403. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-8; Code 1998, § 15.04.060; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
ARTICLE 2. - CODES ADOPTED 

Sec. 15.04.070. - State Uniform Dwelling Code. 
A.  State Code Adopted. The administrative code provisions describing and defining regulations with respect to one- and two-family dwellings in the Wisconsin Administrative Code are adopted and by reference made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth herein, this includes new, existing, moved buildings, alterations, additions and accessory structures. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by an administrative code provision incorporated herein by reference is required or prohibited by this chapter. Any future amendments, revisions, or modifications of the administrative code provisions incorporated herein are intended to be made part of this chapter to secure uniform statewide regulation of one- and two-family dwellings in the city. A copy of these administrative code provisions and any future amendments shall be kept on file in the building inspector's office. 
B.  Existing Buildings. The Wisconsin Uniform Dwelling Code shall also apply to buildings and conditions where: 
1.  An existing building to be occupied as a one- or two-family dwelling, which building was not previously so occupied; 
2.  Additions and alterations, regardless of cost, made to an existing building when deemed necessary in the opinion of the building inspector shall comply with the requirements of this chapter for new buildings: 
Any addition or alteration, regardless of cost, made to a building shall be made in conformity with applicable sections of this chapter; 
3.  Any structure moved to a new location. 
C.  Definitions. As used in this chapter: 
1.  Addition means new construction performed on a dwelling which increases the outside dimensions of the dwelling. 
2.  Alteration means a substantial change or modification other than an addition or minor repair to a dwelling or to systems involved within a dwelling. 
3.  Department means the State of Wisconsin department which is in charge of building codes. 
4.  Dwelling means: 
a.  Any building, the initial construction of which is commenced on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived which contains one or two dwelling units; or 
b.  An existing structure, or that part of an existing structure, which is used or intended to be used as a one- or two-family dwelling. 
5.  Minor repair means repairs performed for maintenance or replacement purposes on any existing one- or two-family dwelling which does not affect room arrangement, light and ventilation, access to or efficiency of any exit stairways or exits, fire protection or exterior aesthetic appearance and which does not increase a given occupancy and use. No building permit is required for work to be performed which is deemed minor repair. 
6.  One- or two-family dwelling means a building structure which contains one or separate households intended to be used as a home, residence or sleeping place by an individual or by two or more individuals maintaining a common household to the exclusion of all others. 
7.  Person means an individual, partnership, firm or corporation. 
8.  Uniform Dwelling Code means those administrative code provisions and any future amendments, revisions, or modifications thereto, contained in the chapters of the Wisconsin Administrative Code, which deal with one- or two-family dwellings. 
D.  Method of Enforcement. 
1.  Certification. The building inspector shall be certified for inspection purposes by the department in each of the categories specified under the Wisconsin Administrative Code. 
2.  Duties. The building inspector shall administer and enforce all provisions of this chapter and the Uniform Dwelling Code. 
3.  Inspection Powers. The building inspector or an authorized certified agent may at all reasonable hours enter upon any public or private premises for inspection purposes and may require the production of the permit for any building, plumbing, electrical or heating work. No person shall interfere with or refuse to permit access to any such premises to the building inspector or his/her agent while in performance of his/her duties. 
4.  Records. The building inspector shall perform all administrative tasks required by the department under the Uniform Dwelling Code. In addition, the inspector shall keep a record of all applications for building permits and shall regularly number each permit in the order of its issue. Also, a record showing the number, description, and size of all buildings erected indicating cost of each building and aggregate cost of all one- and two-family dwellings shall be kept. The building inspector shall make a written annual report to the common council relative to these matters. 
E.  Alterations and Additions to Existing Buildings. 
1.  The provisions of the Uniform Dwelling Code, shall apply to all alterations and additions of all one- and two-family dwellings, regardless of the date of construction. 
2.  Additions and alterations shall include, but are not limited to, new rooms, decks and porches whether roofed or not, new siding that replaces old siding, and new roofs where the rafters or sheathing are replaced. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-3; Code 1998, § 15.04.070; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
State Law reference- One- and two-family dwelling code, Wis. Stats. § 101.60 et seq.; local authority, Wis. Stats. § 101.65. 
Sec. 15.04.080. - Construction standards codes. 
A.  Portions of State Building Code Adopted. The Wisconsin State Commercial Building Code is adopted and made a part of this chapter with respect to those classes of commercial buildings to which this building code specifically applies. Any future amendments, revisions and modifications of any chapter incorporated herein are intended to be made a part of this Code. A copy of the commercial building code and amendments thereto shall be kept on file in the office of the building inspector. 
B.  State Plumbing Code Adopted. The provisions and regulations of Wis. Stats. ch. 145 and the Wisconsin Plumbing Code are made a part of this chapter by reference and shall extend over and govern the installation of all plumbing installed, altered or repaired in the city. Any further amendments, revisions and modifications of the Wisconsin State Statutes and administrative code herein are intended to be made part of this chapter. 
C.  Electrical Code Adopted. The National Electrical Code with the changes, additions or omissions specified in the State of Wisconsin Electrical Codes, are made a part of this chapter by reference and shall extend over and govern the installation of all electrical work, altered or repaired in the city. Any further amendments, revisions and modifications of the administrative code and Wisconsin State Statutes herein are intended to be made part of this chapter. 
D.  Conflicts. If in the opinion of the building inspector and the common council, the provisions of the State Commercial Building Code adopted by Subsection A of this section shall conflict with the provisions of the Federal Housing Administration standards in their application to any proposed building or structure, the inspector and/or the city shall apply the most stringent provisions in determining whether or not the proposed building meets the requirements of this section. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-4; Code 1998, § 15.04.080; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
State Law reference- One- and two- family dwelling code, Wis. Stats. § 101.60 et seq.; modular home code, Wis. Stats. § 101.70 et seq.; electrical wiring and electricians, Wis. Stats. § 101.80 et seq.; manufactured homes and mobile homes, Wis. Stats. § 101.91 et seq.; multifamily dwelling code, Wis. Stats. § 101.971 et seq.; elevators, escalators and other conveyances, Wis. Stats. § 101.981 et seq.; local authority relative to buildings and construction, Wis. Stats. §§ 101.65, 101.76, 101.86, 101.861, 101.975. 
ARTICLE 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 15.04.090. - Permit required. 
    No building of any kind shall be moved within or into the city and no new building or structure, or any part thereof, shall hereafter be erected, or ground broken for same, or enlarged, altered, moved, demolished, razed or used within the city, except as herein provided, until a permit therefor shall first have been obtained by the owner, or his/her authorized agent, from the building inspector. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(a)(1); Code 1998, § 15.04.090; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.100. - Application. 
    Application for a building permit shall be made in writing upon a form furnished by the building inspector or his/her designee and shall state the name and address of the owner of the land and also the owner of the building if different, the legal description of the land upon which the building is to be located, the name and address of the designer, the use to which the building is to be put and such other information as the building inspector may require. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(b); Code 1998, § 15.04.100; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.110. - Site plan approval. 
A.  Submission Required. All applicants for building permits for any construction, reconstruction, expansion or conversion shall submit a site plan and sufficient plans and specifications of proposed buildings, machinery, and operations to enable the building inspector or his/her expert consultants to determine whether the proposed application meets all the requirements applicable thereto in this chapter. 
B.  Review. The building inspector shall make a preliminary review of the application and plans requiring site plan review to determine whether the application and plans meet all the requirements applicable thereto in this chapter. Within 30 days of his/her receipt of the application, the building inspector may issue or refuse a building permit. Applications for mobile home parks, subdivisions, planned unit developments, manmade lakes or ponds, and parking lots, shall be reviewed and approved or denied by the planning commission. 
C.  Requirements for Consideration. In acting on any site plan, the building inspector or the planning commission shall consider the following: 
1.  The appropriateness of the site plan and buildings in relation to the physical character of the site and the usage of adjoining land areas; 
2.  Construction along highways shall be in accordance with the city's downtown revitalization ordinance and historical ordinance; 
3.  The layout of the site with regard to entrances and exits to public streets; the arrangement and improvement of interior roadways; the location, adequacy and improvement of areas for parking and for loading and unloading; and shall in this connection, satisfy itself that the traffic pattern generated by the proposed construction or use shall be developed in a manner consistent with the safety of residents and the community, and the applicant shall so design the construction or use as to minimize any traffic hazard created thereby; 
4.  The adequacy of the proposed water supply, drainage facilities and sanitary and waste disposal; 
5.  The landscaping and appearance of the completed site. The building inspector or the planning commission may require that those portions of all front, rear and side yards not used for off-street parking shall be attractively planted with trees, shrubs, plants or grass lawns, and that the site be effectively screened so as not to impair the value of adjacent properties nor impair the intent of purposes of this section. 
D.  Effect on Municipal Services. Before granting any site approval, the building inspector or the planning commission may, besides obtaining advice from consultants, secure such advice as may be deemed necessary from other municipal officials, with special attention to the effect of such approval upon existing municipal services and utilities. Should additional facilities be needed, the building inspector or the planning commission shall not issue the final approval until the city has entered into an agreement with the applicant regarding the development of such facilities. 
E.  Appeals. Denials of building permits contingent upon site plan approval may be appealed to the zoning board of appeals by filing a notice of appeal with the city clerk within 30 days of the denial. 
F.  Driveway Requirements. See Chapter 12.12. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(c); Code 1998, § 15.04.110; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.120. - Dedicated street and approved subdivision required. 
    Unless a waiver is granted by the common council, following a recommendation from the building inspector, no building permit shall be issued unless the property on which the building is proposed to be built abuts a street that has been dedicated for street purposes. No building permits shall be issued until the subdivision and/or certified survey and required improvements are accepted by the common council. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(d); Code 1998, § 15.04.120; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.130. - Utilities required for residential and nonresidential buildings. 
    No building permit shall be issued for the construction of any building until sewer, water, storm sewer, grading and streets are installed in the streets necessary to service the property for which the permit is required. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(e); Code 1998, § 15.04.130; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.140. - Additional submission requirements for specific permits. 
    The following drawings and information are required, when applying for a building permit: 
A.  Uniform Dwelling Code Permit. 
1.  Two sets of drawings (plot plan, floor plans, elevations, cross-sections, drainage and erosion control); 
2.  One set of heat loss calculations; 
3.  Legal description; 
4.  Completely fill out and sign permit application; 
5.  Supply name and license/certification number of builder, electrician, heating contractor, and plumber; 
6.  Pay permit fee. Applicant will be called when permit is ready; 
7.  Building plans shall be either drawn to scale or fully dimensioned and shall contain the following information: 
a.  Plot Plan or Site Plan. 
i.  Prominent terrain features; 
ii.  Utility lines and easements; 
iii.  Location of all proposed and existing structures and improvements, with distances from lot lines and each other; 
iv.  Proposed and existing grades (including on abutting lots); 
v.  Watercourses and drainage ditches; 
vi.  Eventual floodplain; 
vii.  If located on a corner, indicate any sight obstructions in "vision triangle" 35 feet back from each street; 
viii.  North arrow; 
ix.  Drainage drawing showing discharge of water from the parcel to ditch, storm sewer or other; 
x.  Soil erosion control measures showing silt fences, existing vegetation, earth stockpiles and gravel driveway. 
b.  Basement and/or Foundation Plan. 
i.  Construction materials; 
ii.  Footing sizes; 
iii.  Columns and beams; 
iv.  Insulation; 
v.  Chimney (rating); 
vi.  Heating appliance (name, number and size); 
vii.  Other appliances; 
viii.  Sump; 
ix.  Floor drain; 
x.  Plumbing fixtures; 
xi.  Exterior faucets; 
xii.  Electrical devices and fixtures; 
xiii.  Windows; 
xiv.  Stair or access opening; 
xv.  Smoke detector. 
c.  Plan of Each Level. 
i.  Size and location of rooms, doors and exits, and windows; 
ii.  Stairs, including headroom and railings; 
iii.  Insulation; 
iv.  Fire separation between dwelling and garage; 
v.  Smoke detector; 
vi.  Attic access; 
vii.  Plumbing fixtures; 
viii.  Electrical fixtures and devices; 
ix.  Vents and fans. 
d.  Cross-Section. 
i.  Exterior grade; 
ii.  Structural features, including material, grade and the sizing of foundation or wall, floor, joist or beam, column, lintel or header, rafter or truss, and studs; 
iii.  Insulation; 
iv.  Finish materials; 
v.  Siding; 
vi.  Roofing. 
e.  Elevations (All Sides). 
i.  Exterior appearance including doors; windows and chimney; 
ii.  Ventilation openings (crawlspace, soffit and attic); 
iii.  Grade. 
8.  If the structure, or any part thereof, is a manufactured dwelling, also include: 
a.  Manufacturer and model number; 
b.  Anchorage of dwelling to foundation. 
9.  Apply for sewer and water hook-up permit from City Hall. 
B.  Commercial Code Permit. 
1.  One set of state- or city-approved plans to include plot plan, floor plans, elevations and sections, and erosion control, including plumbing plans, when applicable; 
2.  The plot plan shall include the following required information: 
a.  Prominent terrain features; 
b.  Utility lines and easements; 
c.  Location of all proposed and existing structures and improvements, with distances from lot lines and each other; 
d.  Proposed and existing grades (including on abutting lots); 
e.  Watercourses and drainage ditches; 
f.  Eventual floodplain; 
g.  If located on a corner, indicate any sight obstructions in "vision triangle" 35 feet back from each street; 
h.  There shall be a north arrow indicator on the plot plan; 
i.  Drainage drawing showing discharge of water from the parcel to ditch, storm sewer or other; 
j.  Soil erosion control measures showing silt fences, existing vegetation, earth stockpiles and gravel driveway; 
k.  Landscaping; 
3.  One set of heat loss calculations; 
4.  Legal description; 
5.  Completely fill out and sign permit application; 
6.  Supply name and license/certification number of builder, electrician, heating contractor, and plumber; 
7.  Applicant will be called when permit is ready, and informed of the amount of the permit fee; 
8.  The fee is due when the permit is picked up; 
9.  Apply for sewer and water hook-up permit from City Hall. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(f); Code 1998, § 15.04.140; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.150. - Waiver of plans; minor repairs. 
A.  Waiver. If the building inspector finds that the character of the work is sufficiently described in the application, he/she may waive the filing of plans for alterations, repairs or moving. 
B.  Minor Repairs. The building inspector may authorize minor repairs or maintenance work on any structure or to plumbing, electrical, heating, ventilating or air conditioning systems installed which are valued at less than $1,000.00 which do not change the occupancy area, exterior aesthetic appearance, structural strength, fire protection, exits, light or ventilation of the building or structure without issuance of a building permit. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(g); Code 1998, § 15.04.150; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.160. - Approval of plans; permit issuance. 
A.  If the building inspector determines that the building will comply with this chapter and with other applicable ordinances and orders of the city, he/she shall issue a building permit which shall state the use to which the building is to be put, which shall be kept and displayed at the site of the proposed building. After being approved, the plans and specifications shall not be altered in any respect which involves any of the above mentioned ordinances, laws or orders, or which involves the safety of the building or the occupants, except with the written consent of the building inspector. 
B.  In case adequate plans are presented for part of the building only, the building inspector, at his/her discretion, may issue a permit for that part of the building before receiving the plans and specifications for the entire building. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(h); Code 1998, § 15.04.160; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.170. - Inspection of work. 
    The state-certified inspector is authorized and directed to administer and enforce all provisions of the Wisconsin Administrative Code related to his/her certification. The builder shall notify the building inspector when ready for inspections and the building inspector will inspect after notification all buildings at the following states of construction: 
A.  Footings; Prior to Placing Concrete. Since ground under footings should not be unnecessarily exposed to rain, groundwater, snow or frost, concrete can be placed four hours after notification, even if inspection is not made. In that case leave edge of the minimum eight-inches wall footing exposed several places, and edge of the minimum 12-inches column and chimney footings exposed on one side of each, on one- or two-family dwellings, and the plan approved sizes on commercial buildings, include three or more unit apartment buildings, so it can be seen at the time of the foundation inspection. 
B.  Foundation Walls. After exterior drain tile, gravel, waterproofing and perimeter insulation, and prior to back filling on dwellings. (Basement foundations only on commercial buildings.) 
C.  Under Floor Plumbing. Prior to interior back fill and floor. (This includes sump and drain tile.) 
D.  Rough-in. After roofing, siding, subfloor, plumbing pipes, electrical wiring, heating pipes and/or ducts, prior to interior wall and ceiling materials and insulation. 
E.  Insulation. After insulation and vapor barrier, prior to wall and ceiling materials. 
F.  Final. Prior to occupancy. 
G.  Inspections . Inspections will be made within 48 hours of notification (weekends and holidays excepted). If the inspection is not made within this time, construction can continue after the 48 hours is up. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(i); Code 1998, § 15.04.170; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.180. - Denial of access; inspection warrants. 
    If the building inspector is denied access to inspect a property, he/she may request the city attorney to seek an inspection warrant pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0119. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(j); Code 1998, § 15.04.180; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.190. - Final inspection and compliance certificate. 
A.  The building inspector shall make a final inspection of all new buildings, additions and alterations. 
B.  No building nor part thereof shall be occupied until such inspection has been made, nor shall any building be occupied in any manner which conflicts with the conditions set forth in the permit. The responsible party or parties, whether the builder and/or owner, who occupies a building before the final inspection shall be subject to a citation, along with other penalties as provided in this chapter. It shall be the responsibility of the responsible party, whether the builder and/or owner, to inform building tenants of the final inspection requirement. 
C.  A compliance certificate will be issued upon request when the final inspection has been made, and eventual nonconforming and missing items corrected. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(k)(1); Code 1998, § 15.04.190; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.200. - Electrical permits. 
A.  Code Compliance. Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, all installations of electrical equipment shall conform to and comply with the State Electrical Code, the Wisconsin State Statutes, this chapter and any orders, rules and regulations issued by authority thereof, and with approved electrical standards for safety to persons and property. Where no specific standards for safety are prescribed by this chapter or by the State Electrical Code, conformity with the regulations set forth in the State Electrical Code and in the National Electrical Safety Code shall be prima facie evidence of conformity with approved standards for safety to persons and property. 
B.  Permit Required. Before any electrical wires or electrical apparatus shall be installed for lighting or power purposes, or any electrical construction work done, except minor repair work, a permit therefor shall be obtained from the building inspector by the owner or a licensed electrician. A permit shall be on the same form used for building permits and shall state clearly the work planned, alterations to be made, and equipment and materials to be used, and all later deviations from such plan must be submitted to and approved by the building inspector. "Minor repair work" means the replacement of broken or defective sockets, snap, push or toggle switches, convenience outlets, and portable electrical appliances. 
C.  Inspections. Electrical inspections are to be performed as outlined in Section 15.04.170. 
D.  Underground Wiring Required. All telephone, utility, cable television and electric cable hereafter installed outside of any city right-of-way and which are to serve residential, commercial or industrial property shall be buried underground. This requirement shall include feeder cables and individual service connections. The electrical inspector may waive this requirement for any of the following reasons: 
1.  The location, topography, soil, solid rock, boulders, or other physical conditions would make underground installation unreasonable or impractical; or 
2.  The lots to be served by the facilities can be served directly from existing overhead facilities. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-5; Code 1998, § 15.04.200; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997; Ord. No. 401(part), 2005) 
State Law reference- Electrical wiring and electricians, Wis. Stats. § 101.80 et seq.; local authority Wis. Stats. § 101.86. 
Sec. 15.04.210. - Heating, ventilating and air conditioning permits. 
A.  Code Compliance. Except as otherwise provided by this chapter all installations of heating, ventilating and air conditioning equipment shall comply with the state heating, ventilating, and air conditioning codes, the Wisconsin State Statutes, this chapter and any orders, rules and regulations issued by authority thereof. 
B.  Permit Required. 
1.  Before any piping, duct or equipment shall be installed, except for minor work, a permit shall be obtained from the building inspector. 
2.  The application for such permit will be on the same form used for a building permit, and shall state clearly the work planned, and material and equipment used, and all later deviations must be submitted and approved by the building inspector. 
C.  Inspections. Heating, ventilating and air conditioning inspections are to be performed as outlined in Section 15.04.170. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-6; Code 1998, § 15.04.210; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.220. - Plumbing permits. 
A.  Permit to Connect With Public Sewer System Required. No person, firm or corporation shall open any street, alley or public place for the purpose of connecting to a sewer lateral or other terminal, lay any house sewer or drain pipe or make any attachment or extension to any old drain or house sewer, or do any kind of work whatsoever in connection with any public or private sewer outside of any building, except repairs, without first obtaining from the city a written permit to connect with the public sewer system. 
B.  Permit Required Before Laying Drains. No work of laying house sewers or storm drains that are on the premises and in the hands of a master plumber or one employed by him/her, shall be commenced or continued without the required permit. All work on water and sewer laterals shall be performed by state-registered plumbers or pipe layers. 
C.  Permit for Interior Plumbing. 
1.  No interior plumbing work shall be started before obtaining a permit from the building inspector, as outlined in this section. 
2.  All plumbing work inside the foundation of any commercial building, duplex or multifamily building, and inside any new single-family dwelling shall be performed by a master plumber, or a journeyman plumber working under the master's direction. 
D.  Application for Permit. A permit shall be granted only upon written application by a licensed master plumber, authorized by the owner or agent of the premises desiring to make such connection, extension or alteration, and stating the name of the owner and that he/she and such master plumber will be bound by and be subject to all the rules and regulations prescribed and giving the exact location of the premises, stating the purpose for which the connection, extension or alteration is to be used, and the time when the work is to be done and all other particulars in respect thereto. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-7(b); Code 1998, § 15.04.220; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.230. - Permit lapses. 
    A building permit shall lapse and be void unless building operations are commenced and construction has not been substantially completed within two years from the date of issuance thereof. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(l); Code 1998, § 15.04.230; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.240. - Revocation of permits. 
A.  The building inspector or other authorized inspectors may revoke any building, plumbing, heating, ventilation, air conditioning or electrical permit, or approval issued under the regulations of this chapter and may stop construction or use of approved new materials, equipment, methods of construction, devices or appliances for any of the following reasons: 
1.  Whenever the building inspector shall find at any time that applicable ordinances, laws, orders, plans and specifications are not being complied with and that the holder of the permit refused to conform after written warning has been issued to him/her; 
2.  Whenever the continuance of any construction becomes dangerous to life or property; 
3.  Whenever there is any violation of any condition or provisions of the application for permit or of the permit; 
4.  Whenever any false statement or misrepresentation has been made in the application for permit, plans, drawings, data specifications, or certified lot or plot plan on which the issuance of the permit or approval was based; 
5.  Whenever there is a violation of any of the conditions of an approval or occupancy given by the building inspector for the proper use of all materials, equipment, methods or construction devices or appliances. 
B.  The notice revoking a building, electrical, heating, ventilation, air conditioning, or plumbing permit, or approval shall be in writing and may be served upon the applicant of the permit, owner of the premises and his/her agent if any and on the person having charge of construction. 
C.  A revocation placard shall also be posted upon the building, structure, equipment or premises in question by the building inspector. 
D.  After the notice is served upon the persons as aforesaid and posted, it is unlawful for any person to proceed thereafter with any construction operation whatsoever on the premises, and the permit which has been so revoked shall be null and void, and before any construction or operation is again resumed, a new permit, as required by this chapter, shall be procured and fees paid therefor, and thereafter the resumption of any construction or operation shall be in compliance with the regulation of this chapter. However, such work as the inspector may order as a condition precedent to the reissuance of the building permit may be performed, or such work as he/she may require for preservation of life and safety. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(m); Code 1998, § 15.04.240; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.250. - Report of violations. 
    City officers shall report at once to the building inspector any building which is being carried on without a permit as required by this chapter. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(n); Code 1998, § 15.04.250; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.260. - Display of permit. 
    Building permits shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises where the authorized building or work is in progress at all times during construction or work thereon. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(o); Code 1998, § 15.04.260; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
ARTICLE 4. - ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS 

Sec. 15.04.270. - Accessory buildings. 
A.  General. Accessory buildings shall include, but are not limited to, unattached garages, sheds, storage buildings, and boathouses. 
B.  Design. Accessory buildings shall be designed and finished to be compatible with the primary structure, by using similar building methods, materials and colors. 
C.  Methods of Design. 
1.  Generally. Those applicable design requirements set forth in the Wisconsin Dwelling Code, which apply directly to the major structural components of accessory buildings shall be used in the design of such buildings. 
2.  Exceptions. 
a.  Small utility buildings of the portable type and size commonly available as a single unit or kit need not comply with Subsection C.1 of this section, if, in the opinion of the building inspector, such buildings are considered safe and sound. 
b.  Wall studs for garages may be spaced 24 inches on center. 
D.  Foundations. 
1.  Generally. All accessory buildings shall be built on either foundation, floating slabs or piers subject to approval of the building inspector. 
2.  Exception. Buildings of the type described in Subsection C.2.a of this section, may be placed on skids or other similar supports anchored to the ground, subject to approval of the building inspector. 
E.  Grade. The grade shall slope away from the accessory building to provide drainage away from the building. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-10; Code 1998, § 15.04.270; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.280. - Plumbing inspections. 
A.  All plumbing systems or installations within the boundaries of the city and those connecting with the city water or sewerage system beyond the boundaries are subject to inspection as required in this chapter. 
B.  System of Inspection. Plumbing installations inspections will be performed by the following personnel: 
1.  Building inspector: As outlined in Article 3 of this chapter, for piping and appliances inside structures. 
2.  Chief utility operator: Sanitary sewer laterals and water laterals shall be inspected by the utility sewer and water operator. 
3.  Public works: Storm sewer laterals shall be inspected by the Public Works Department. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-7(a)(1) and (2); Code 1998, § 15.04.280; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.290. - Repairs to drainage or waste pipes; responsibility of property owners. 
    Repairs of any drainage or waste pipe carrying domestic sewage from outside the foundation walls of any building or structure to the sewer main, including private domestic sewage treatment and disposal systems, such as stoppage of leaks in supply or waste pipes, clearing stoppages in waste pipes and repairing valves or faucets in the drainage or waste pipe, shall be the sole responsibility of the property owner, and repairs of water pipes from outside the foundation walls to the curb stop shall be the sole responsibility of the property owner. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-7(a)(3); Code 1998, § 15.04.290; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.300. - Excavations. 
A.  Protection of Excavations. When a building permit for any building, which includes in its plans the excavation for a basement or subsurface construction, has been issued by the building inspector it shall be understood that if at any time for any cause after such excavation work shall have commenced subsequent work shall be discontinued for more than 30 days, such owner shall erect all around such excavation a solid barrier, wall or wire fence not less than five feet in height, which barrier, wall or wire fence shall remain in position until work is again commenced and the building inspector is satisfied it will be completed. 
B.  Notice to Owner. If any excavation made comes to the attention of the building inspector and appears to have been discontinued or abandoned, the building inspector shall notify the owner in writing by registered mail that within 30 days of receipt of such notice such owner shall erect a solid suitable wall, barrier or wire fence around such excavation, or cap same to eliminate the danger of any person falling therein or continue construction. Such landowner shall, upon receipt of such notice, erect such wall, wire fence or barrier or cap such excavation. Any failure to do so shall constitute a violation of this section unless construction work is immediately continued. Such wall, wire fence or barrier or capping shall remain in place until the building inspector is satisfied that the removal of the same will be followed by normal and ordinary construction operations. 
C.  Excavations near Street. Whenever any person, whether as owner of any premises or his/her agent or contractor, desires to make an excavation thereon within four feet of any public street or sidewalk, he/she shall place and maintain proper barriers around same until such excavation shall be filled. 
D.  Notice to Adjoining Owner. Whenever an excavation is to be so deep that adjoining walls have to be underpinned, the general contractor shall give adjoining property owners notification of that fact. See the Wisconsin Administrative Code. 
E.  Sheath Piling. All excavations for buildings shall be properly guarded and protected by the excavator and shall be sheath piled whenever necessary to prevent the adjoining soil from caving in. 
F.  Closing of Abandoned Excavations. 
1.  If the landowner fails to comply with the terms of such agreement, or after having been notified as herein provided fails or refuses to comply with the terms of this section, the building inspector shall cause such excavation to be fenced or capped, whichever shall be more economical, at the city's expense, shall keep a record of costs thereof, and certify same to the city administrator who shall place such cost on the tax roll as a charge against the affected real estate and same shall be collected as are other city special charges. 
2.  Any excavation for building purposes or any uncovered foundation which shall remain open for more than 45 days shall be deemed abandoned and a nuisance, the building inspector shall order that unless the erection of the building or structure on the excavation or foundation shall commence or continue forthwith suitable safeguards shall be provided to prevent accidental injury to children or others or the excavation or foundation be filled to grade. An order shall be served upon the owner of record or the owner's agent, who is in charge of the premises, and upon the holder of an encumbrance of record in the manner provided for service of a summons in the circuit court. If the owner or the holder of an encumbrance of record cannot be found, the order may be served by posting it on the premises and making publication in the official newspaper for two consecutive publications at least ten days before the time for compliance stated in the order commences to run. Such time shall be not less than 14 days nor more than 20 days after service. If the owner of the land fails to comply with the order within the time required, the building inspector shall cause the excavation or foundation to be filled to grade. The cost of such abatement shall be charged against the real estate and entered on the next succeeding tax roll as a special charge and shall bear interest at a rate established by council from the date of the building inspector's report on cost thereof, pursuant to the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 66.0627. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-12(a)-(f); Code 1998, § 15.04.300; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.310. - Vacant buildings. 
    Whenever any building or structure is vacant and the doors and windows or any part thereof have been removed or opened, leaving the interior of such building or structure exposed to the elements and accessible to trespassers, then such building or structure shall be deemed to be dangerous, unsafe and a menace to public safety. The building inspector shall give the owner thereof written notice to secure the building or structure and comply with city code requirements within 30 days of the date of the notice. Failure to comply with the written notice shall be sufficient grounds for the building inspector to condemn and raze the building or structure in accordance with the applicable provisions of Wis. Stats. § 66.0413. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-12(g); Code 1998, § 15.04.310; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.320. - Alterations and repairs. 
    The following provisions shall apply to buildings altered or repaired: 
A.  Alterations. When not in conflict with any regulations, alterations to any existing building or structure accommodating a legal occupancy and use but of substandard type of construction, which involves either beams, girders, columns, bearing or other walls, room, heating and air condition systems, plumbing and electrical systems, arrangement, light and ventilation, changes in location of exit stairways or exits, or any or all of the above, then such existing construction shall be made to conform to the minimum requirements of this chapter applicable to such occupancy and use and given type of construction. 
B.  Repairs. Repairs for purposes of maintenance, or replacements in any existing building or structure, which do not involve the structural portions of the building or structure or which do not affect room arrangement, plumbing, electrical and HVAC systems, light and ventilation, access to or efficiency of any existing stairways, or exits, fire protection, or exterior aesthetic appearance and which do not increase a given occupancy or use, shall be deemed minor repairs, and if total cost of materials is less than $1,000.00 it will not require a permit. 
C.  Alterations When Not Permitted. When any existing building or structure, which, for any reason whatsoever, does not conform to the regulations of this chapter, has deteriorated from any cause whatsoever to an extent greater than 50 percent of the equalized value of the building or structure, no alterations or moving of such building or structure shall be permitted. Any such building or structure shall be considered a menace to public safety and welfare and shall be ordered vacated and thereafter demolished and debris removed from the premises. 
D.  Alterations and Repairs Required. When any of the structural members of any building or structure have deteriorated from any cause whatsoever to less than their required strength, the owner of such a building or structure shall cause such structural members to be restored to their required strength; failing in which the building or structure shall be considered a menace to public safety and shall be vacated and thereafter no further occupancy or use of the same shall be permitted until the regulations of this chapter are complied with. 
E.  Extent of Deterioration. The amount and extent of deterioration of any existing building or structure shall be determined by the building inspector. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(a)(2); Code 1998, § 15.04.320; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.330. - Grades to be established for new construction. 
    For new construction adjacent to existing buildings, the city engineer shall establish the finish grade elevation such that the elevation corresponds with surrounding buildings. For new plats, the city engineer shall establish the finish elevation for each structure which corresponds to the drainage plan provided for such plat. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(a)(3); Code 1998, § 15.04.330; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997; Ord. No. 394(part), 2003) 
Sec. 15.04.340. - Use discontinued. 
A.  Whenever any building or portion thereof is being used or occupied contrary to the provisions of this chapter, the building inspector shall order such use or occupancy discontinued, and the building or portion thereof vacated, by notice served on any person using or causing such use or occupancy to be continued, and such person shall vacate such building or portion thereof within 30 days after receipt of the notice, or make the building or portion thereof comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
B.  Any building, structure, premises or any part thereof, hereafter vacated or damaged by any cause whatsoever so as to jeopardize public safety or health, shall not hereafter be occupied or used until a new permit application has been filed and a new final inspection made. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(k)(2); Code 1998, § 15.04.340; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.350. - Change of use; approval required. 
    It is unlawful to change the use of any building, structure, premises or part thereof without first obtaining from the building inspector an approval of such change in the occupancy or use. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-2(k)(3); Code 1998, § 15.04.350; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.360. - Razing of buildings. 
A.  Permit Required. No building within the city shall be razed without a permit from the building inspector. A snow fence or other approved barricade shall be provided as soon as any portion of the building is removed and shall remain during razing operations. After all razing operations have been completed, the foundation shall be filled at least one foot above the adjacent grade, the property raked clean and all debris hauled away. Razing permits shall lapse and be void unless the work authorized thereby is commenced within six months from the date thereof or completed within 30 days from the date of commencement of the work. Any unfinished portion of work remaining beyond the required 30 days must have special approval from the building inspector. 
B.  Debris Removal. All debris must be hauled away at the end of each week for the work that was done during that week. No combustible material shall be used for back filling, but shall be hauled away. There shall not be any burning of materials on the site of the razed building. 
C.  Dust. If any razing or removal operation under this section results in, or would likely result in, an excessive amount of dust particles in the air creating a nuisance in the vicinity thereof, the permittee shall take all necessary steps, by use of water spraying or other appropriate means, to eliminate such nuisance. 
D.  Insects and Rodents. The permittee shall take all necessary steps, prior to the razing of a building, through the employment of a qualified person in the field of pest control or by other appropriate means, to treat the building as to prevent the spread and migration of rodents and insects therefrom during and after the razing operations. 
E.  Asbestos. State regulations regarding abatement of asbestos shall be followed. 
F.  Basement Concrete Floors. About five percent of the floor shall be removed to allow drainage. 
G.  Utilities. All utilities shall be cut and capped as directed by the utility company, or the city water and sewer department. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-11; Code 1998, § 15.04.360; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.370. - Discharge of clear waters. 
A.  Groundwater Discharge. Where deemed necessary by the building inspector, every house shall have a sump pump installed for the purpose of discharging clear waters from foundation drains and ground infiltration with discharge pipe penetrating the exterior wall above the grade, and the underground pipe connected to the storm sewer lateral which is provided by the developer at the front lot line, and where the building is not serviced by a storm sewer shall either discharge into an underground conduit leading to a drainage ditch, dry well, gutter or shall discharge onto the ground surface in such other manner as will not constitute a nuisance as defined herein. No water shall be discharged within eight feet of a neighboring lot or in such a manner that water will enter a neighboring lot. 
B.  Conducting Tests . If the building inspector or a sewer department employee suspects an illegal clear water discharge as defined by this chapter or by any other applicable provision of the Wisconsin Administrative Code as it may, from time to time, be amended, he/she may, upon reasonable notice and at reasonable times, enter the private premises where such illegal clear water discharge is suspected and conduct appropriate tests to determine whether such suspected illegal clear water discharge actually exists. 
C.  Stormwater Discharge. All roof downspouts from gutters serving roofs larger than 600 square feet (measured horizontally) or which discharge unto paved areas, surface drains, from any mechanical devices, pipes, conduits or any other objects, or things used for the purpose of collecting, conducting, transporting, diverting, draining or discharging of storm waters shall be discharged to a storm sewer lateral, if storm sewer provided in street or to a dry well, an underground conduit leading to a drainage ditch, or onto the ground surface in such other manner as will not constitute a nuisance as defined herein. 
D.  Storm Sewer Lateral. Where municipal storm sewers are provided a lateral shall be installed to the lot line, and underground piping from the building to the lateral shall be at the expense of the owner. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-13; Code 1998, § 15.04.370(C)-(F); Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.380. - Floodplain requirements. 
A.  The full requirements are listed in the existing floodplain ordinance, Chapter 15.24. 
B.  As an interpretation of some of the requirements the following should be noted: 
1.  The floor in the lowest room, and the top of the foundation wall, shall be at least two feet above the 100-year floodplain elevation. Basements are not allowed, and for the purposes of this chapter, a crawlspace with more than three feet from floor to underside of floor joists or trusses, shall be considered a basement. 
2.  Outside drain tile should not be installed, and no opening allowed through footings or foundation walls below two feet above the 100-year floodplain elevation. 
3.  No furnaces, hot water tanks, electrical devices, non-submersible pumps, standpipes or drains connected to the sanitary sewer or other equipment are allowed below the 100-year floodplain elevation. 
4.  Rim of clear water sump shall be flush with the floor. 
5.  Floor in crawlspace shall not be lower than the 100-year floodplain elevation. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-18; Code 1998, § 15.04.380; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.04.390. - Construction site erosion and stormwater runoff control. 
A.  Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Code the provisions of the Wisconsin Construction Site Best Management Practice Handbook are adopted and by reference and made a part of this Code as if fully set forth herein. 
B.  The erosion control measures required by the state building codes shall be followed. 
(Prior Code, § 15-2-1; Code 1998, § 15.04.390; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
ARTICLE 5. - VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES 

Sec. 15.04.400. - Violations; penalties. 
A.  Any building or structure hereafter erected, enlarged, altered or repaired or any use hereafter established in violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed an unlawful building, structure or use. The building inspector or other authorized inspectors shall promptly report all such violations to the council and city attorney who shall bring an action to enjoin the erection, enlargement, alteration, repair or moving of such building or structure or the establishment of such use of buildings in violation of this chapter or to cause such building, structure or use to be removed and may also be subject to a penalty as provided in general penalty provisions of this Code. In any such action, the fact that a permit was issued shall not constitute a defense, nor shall any error, oversight or dereliction of duty on the part of the building inspector or other city officials constitute a defense. Compliance with the provisions of this chapter may also be enforced by injunctional order at the suit of the owner or owners of any real estate within the jurisdiction of this chapter. 
B.  Violations. 
1.  If an inspection reveals a noncompliance with this chapter or the Uniform Dwelling Code, the building inspector shall notify the applicant and the owner, in writing, of the violation to be corrected. All cited violations shall be corrected within 30 days after written notification, unless an extension is granted. 
2.  A stop-work order may be posted at the construction site. A stop-work order shall not be removed except by written notice of the building inspector after satisfactory evidence has been supplied that the cited violation has been corrected. 
3.  Each day each violation continues after the 30 day written notice period has run shall constitute a separate offense. Nothing in this chapter shall preclude the city from maintaining any appropriate action to prevent or remove a violation of any provision of this chapter or the Uniform Dwelling Code. 
4.  If any construction or work governed by the provisions of this chapter or the Uniform Dwelling Code is commenced prior to the issuance of a permit, triple fees shall be charged. 
C.  Any person feeling aggrieved by an order or a determination of the building inspector may appeal from such order or determination to the zoning board of appeals. Those procedures customarily used to effectuate an appeal to the zoning board of appeals shall apply. 
D.  Except as may otherwise be provided by statute or ordinance, no officer, agent or employee of the city charged with the enforcement of this chapter shall render himself/herself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his/her duties under this chapter. Any suit brought against any officer, agent or employee of the city as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his/her duties under this chapter shall be defended by the legal representative of the city until the final determination of the proceedings therein. 
(Prior Code, § 15-1-17; Code 1998, § 15.04.400; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
CHAPTER 15.08. - HOUSING CODE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Ordinances placing certain limits or requirements on landlords, Wis. Stats. § 66.0104. 

Sec. 15.08.010. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and cited as the "Minimum Housing Code of the City of Omro." 
(Prior Code, § 15-4-1; Code 1998, § 15.08.010; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.08.020. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to prevent the deterioration of residential units in neighborhoods and to ensure a minimum level of housing standards for the residents of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 15-4-2; Code 1998, § 15.08.020; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.08.030. - Scope and construction. 
A.  This chapter shall pertain to all dwellings. 
B.  Such units or neighborhoods could become so dilapidated and neglected that they jeopardize or are detrimental to the health, safety, morals or general welfare of the people of the city, or to the economic values of adjoining property. 
C.  The adoption and subsequent enforcement of the ordinance codified in this chapter is therefore deemed essential to the public interest. It shall be reasonably construed to maintain a pleasant, safe and healthful environment, and to help insure the maintenance of property values within the city. 
(Prior Code, § 15-4-3; Code 1998, § 15.08.030; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.08.040. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter: 
1.  Accessory structure means a garage, storage building, boathouse, etc. 
2.  Apartment hotel means the same as "Hotel." 
3.  Approved means in accordance with regulation established by city ordinance or code and authority designated by law to enforce such ordinance or code. 
4.  Basement means a subordinate use which is incidental to and customary in conjunction with the principal structure or use and which is located on the same lot with such principal structure or use. 
5.  Bath means a bathtub or shower and stall properly be connected with both hot and cold waterlines. 
6.  Bathroom means a nonhabitable room within a dwelling unit which is used, or intended to be used, primarily for bathing and/or toilet purposes, and which contains a toilet, lavatory, bathtub or shower facilities. 
7.  Bedroom means a habitable room within a dwelling unit which is used, or intended to be used, primarily for the purpose of sleeping, but shall not include any kitchen or dining room. The term "bedroom," however, shall not be interpreted so as to prohibit efficiency apartments. 
8.  Building inspector means a housing or health inspector, public works employee, or any other city employee authorized by the city council to perform inspections. 
9.  City means the City of Omro, Wisconsin. 
10.  Communal means used or shared by, or intended to be used or shared by, the occupants of two or more rooming units or two or more dwelling units. 
11.  Dwelling means a structure or portion thereof designed or used exclusively for human habitation, including home trailers, mobile homes, and manufactured dwellings, but not including hotels, motels, boardinghouses and lodginghouses, tourist courts or tourist homes. 
12.  Dwelling, multiple or apartment building. "Multiple dwelling" or "apartment building" means a residential structure, or portion of a structure, containing three or more dwelling units served by a common entrance, or a structure designed for occupancy by three or more families. 
13.  Dwelling, single-family. "Single-family dwelling" means a structure on a single lot containing one dwelling unit and surrounded by open space or yards, and which is not attached to any other dwelling by any means. 
14.  Dwelling, two-family. "Two-family dwelling" means a structure on a single lot containing two dwelling units, each of which is totally separated from the other by an unpierced wall extending from ground to roof or an unpierced ceiling and floor extending from exterior wall to exterior wall, except for a common stairwell exterior to both dwelling units. 
15.  Dwelling unit means a room or suite of rooms used as a single-family dwelling including bath and culinary accommodations. 
16.  Efficiency apartment means a dwelling unit consisting of one habitable room. 
17  Extermination means the control and elimination of insects, rodents or other pests by elimination of their harborage places, by removing and making inaccessible material that may serve as their food, by poisoning, spraying, trapping or by any other recognized and legal elimination methods approved by the health officer of the city. 
18.  Family means one or more persons maintaining a common household. 
19.  Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the preparation, handling, cooking and consumption of food. 
20.  Habitable room means a room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking or eating purposes, excluding bathrooms, laundries, pantries, foyers, communicating corridors, closets and storage spaces. 
21.  Hotel means a structure in which lodging, or boarding and lodging are provided and offered to the public for compensation, and in which ingress and egress to and from all rooms are made through an inside lobby or office supervised by a person in charge at all times. As such, it is open to the public in contradistinction to a boarding house, which is herein separately defined. 
22.  Infestation means the presence of any insects, rodents or other pests within a dwelling or on the dwelling premises. 
23.  Inoperable vehicle means any unregistered vehicle, or any vehicle unable to move under its own power or unable to be used legally on any public street. 
24.  Kitchen means a habitable room, or an area used, or intended to be used for cooking or the preparation of meals. 
25.  Nuisance is defined as follows: 
1.  Any attractive nuisance, which may prove detrimental to children whether in a building or upon a lot. This includes any abandoned wells, shafts, basements and excavations; or any abandoned refrigerators and inoperable motor vehicles; or any structurally unsound structure; or any lumber and other construction material, trash, debris or vegetation which may prove a hazard for inquisitive minors; 
2.  Whatever is dangerous to human life or is detrimental to health; 
3.  Overcrowding a room with occupants; 
4.  Insufficient ventilation or illumination; 
5.  Inadequate or unsanitary sewerage or plumbing facilities; 
6.  Uncleanliness; 
7.  Whatever renders the air, food or drink unwholesome or is detrimental to the health of human beings; 
8.  Unsafe or dangerous electrical wiring, plumbing systems or heating equipment. 
26.  Occupant means any person living, sleeping, eating or having actual possession of a dwelling unit or rooming unit. 
27.  Operator means any person which is in charge or control of a building or part thereof in which dwelling units or rooming units are let. 
28.  Owner means any person who alone or jointly or severally with others is the legally recorded holder of the title with or without actual possession thereof, or who has charge, care or control of any dwelling or dwelling unit as agent or owner or as executor, administrator, trustee or guardian of the estate of the owner. The term "owner" under this chapter shall also include the legally recorded holder of a land contract vendee interest. 
29.  Person means any individual, firm, corporation, partnership or association. 
30.  Plumbing means all piping, fixtures, appliances, equipment, devices and appurtenances in connection with the water supply, water distribution and drainage systems, including hot water storage tanks, water softeners and water heaters connected with such water and drainage systems and also includes the installation thereof or a water pressure system other than municipal systems as provided in Wis. Stats. ch. 144. 
31.  Premises means a lot together with all buildings and structures thereon. 
32.  Roomer means an occupant of a roominghouse, who is not a member of the family of the operator of that roominghouse, or an occupant of a dwelling unit who is not a member of the family occupying the dwelling units. 
33.  Roominghouse means any dwelling or that part of any dwelling, containing one or more rooming units, in which space is let by the owner or operator to more than four roomers. 
34.  Rooming unit means any room or group of rooms forming a single habitable unit in a roominghouse used or intended to be used for living and/or sleeping. 
35.  Rubbish means household waste, except garbage; and the term shall include tin cans, glass, metal, crockery and similar household wastes; also papers, rags, lawn rakings and other combustible refuse. 
36  Supplied means paid for, furnished or provided by or under the control of the owner/operator. 
B.  Meaning of Certain Words. 
1.  Whenever the words: "dwelling," "dwelling unit," "roominghouse," or "premises" are used in this chapter, they shall be construed as though they were followed by "or any part thereof." 
2.  All words other than those specifically defined in this chapter shall have their ordinarily accepted meanings as implied by the context. 
(Prior Code, § 15-4-4; Code 1998, § 15.08.040; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.08.050. - Inspection of premises. 
A.  The building or housing inspector is authorized and directed to make inspections when he/she has valid reasons to believe that a violation of this chapter has occurred. 
B.  The building or housing inspector is authorized to enter and inspect all dwellings and dwelling units, subject to the provisions of this chapter, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. (except for Sundays and holidays), for the purpose of determining whether there is compliance with the provisions of this chapter. He/she shall give the occupant thereof, or if there is none, then the owner thereof, reasonable notice of his/her intent to inspect the premises and may then make his/her inspection only if he/she is given permission to do so. In the absence of such permission, he/she shall obtain a special inspection warrant issued pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0119 before entering the premises. However, if delay in the inspection would pose a serious and imminent threat to human life, health or property, he/she may enter the premises without such permission or notice and with or without such a warrant as the circumstances may prescribe. The building inspector and the owner or occupant in charge may agree as to an inspection time by appointment at a time other than during the hours specified above. 
C.  If any owner, occupant or other person in charge of a dwelling or dwelling unit subject to the provisions of this chapter refuses, impedes, inhibits, interferes with, restricts or obstructs entry and free access to any part of the structural premises where inspection authorized by this chapter is sought, the building inspector may seek from any court of competent jurisdiction, an order that such owner, occupant or other person in charge cease and desist from such interference. 
(Prior Code, § 15-4-5; Code 1998, § 15.08.050; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.08.060. - Notice of violation. 
    Whenever the building inspector determines that there has been a violation or that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter, he/she shall give written notice of such violation or alleged violation to the party responsible for maintaining the premises in compliance with this chapter or agent as designated in writing. The notice shall: 
A.  Include a description of real estate sufficient for identification; 
B.  Include a statement of the alleged violation or violations; 
C.  Include an order for remedial action; 
D.  Allow reasonable time, of up to six months, for performance of any action required; 
E.  Be served upon the responsible party or agent as designated in writing; provided, however, that such notice shall be deemed to be properly served upon such party, if a copy thereof is delivered to him personally or if not found, by leaving a copy thereof at his/her usual place of abode, in the presence of someone of the family of suitable age and discretion who shall be informed of the contents thereof, or by sending a copy thereof by certified mail, with return receipt required, to his/her last known address, or if the certified letter with the copy is returned with a receipt showing it has not been delivered to him, by posting a copy thereof in a conspicuous place in or about the dwelling affected by the notice. 
(Prior Code, § 15-4-6; Code 1998, § 15.08.060; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.08.070. - Minimum housing board created. 
A.  In order to provide for reasonable interpretation of the provisions of this chapter, there is created a minimum housing board, consisting of five members who are qualified by experience and training to pass upon matters pertaining to housing. 
B.  The minimum housing board shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by council. The building inspector shall be an ex officio member. 
C.  Any person affected by any notice which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of this chapter may request and shall be granted a reasonable interpretation. 
D.  Interpretations must be requested within the time limitations specified on the noncompliance notice. A one-week notice must be given to the minimum housing board for all meetings. A meeting with the minimum housing board shall not alter or extend the date that compliance must be made by. 
(Prior Code, § 15-4-7; Code 1998, § 15.08.070; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.08.080. - Emergency orders. 
A.  If the building inspector shall determine that a dwelling or accessory structure is in such condition that it constitutes a public nuisance and that there is great and immediate danger to the public health, safety and welfare and if the owner, or occupant if appropriate, refuses to comply with orders within the time prescribed, the building inspector, or other designated officer, shall cause such building or part thereof to be closed if unfit for human habitation, occupancy, or use. The inspector shall post a placard on the premises containing the following words: "This building cannot be used for human habitation, occupancy or other use." 
B.  It is the duty of the building inspector, or other designated officer, to prohibit the use of the building or part thereof for human habitation, occupancy or use until the necessary repairs have been made. The procedure followed shall be pursuant to Section 15.08.060. 
(Prior Code, § 15-4-8; Code 1998, § 15.08.080; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.08.090. - Unauthorized removal of notice. 
    No person shall interfere with, obstruct, mutilate, deface or remove the official notice or placard from any dwelling or from dwelling unit. 
(Prior Code, § 15-4-9; Code 1998, § 15.08.090; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.08.100. - Minimum standards for equipment and facilities. 
    All habitable buildings subject to the provisions of this chapter shall comply with the following requirements for basic equipment and facilities: 
A.  Sinks. Every dwelling shall contain a kitchen sink which shall be located in the room in which the food is cooked or prepared. 
B.  Bathrooms. Every dwelling shall contain a bath, a flush toilet, and a lavatory basin, irrespective of the sink required as a kitchen facility, except that where there are apartments consisting of not more than three rooms, there shall be at least one water closet for each two such apartments. The room wherein the flush toilet, lavatory basin, and bathtub or shower required under this section are installed, shall afford privacy to a person within. The bathtub or shower may be in a room separate from the room housing the toilet and lavatory basin, but shall afford privacy to the person within. 
C.  Water Supply. Every required kitchen sink, lavatory basin, bathtub or shower shall be properly connected with both hot and cold potable water, and every flush water closet shall be properly connected to a supply of water adequate in volume and pressure for flushing purposes. 
D.  Water Heating Facilities. Every dwelling unit shall have automatic or manually operated water heating facilities which are properly installed, are maintained in safe and good working condition, are connected to fixtures as required in Subsection C of this section, and are capable of heating water to a temperature of at least 120 degrees above zero Fahrenheit so as to permit an adequate amount of hot water to be drawn at every required sink, lavatory basin, bathtub or shower, even when the required dwelling space heating facilities are not in operation. 
E.  Garbage and Refuse Receptacles. Every dwelling unit shall have adequate disposal equipment or receptacles for garbage and rubbish large enough to hold all garbage and rubbish generated by the dwelling unit. Such receptacles shall comply with the requirements and standards set forth by the department of public works and the city health officer. 
F.  Stairways. Stairways in dwellings and dwelling units shall be of safe and sound construction, equipped with proper handrails, mounted not less than two feet and six inches above the nose of the treads, and equipped with the treads and risers, which are reasonably uniform. Living spaces located above the ground floor shall have two exits. Stairways and exits shall comply with the appropriate provisions of the state building codes contained in the Wisconsin Administrative Code. 
G.  Smoke Detectors. All dwelling units subject to the provisions of this chapter shall be provided with a properly working, approved, listed and labeled smoke detector, which will be located in the basement and on each floor of the dwelling unit, except in the attic or the storage area of the dwelling units. 
1.  The owner or person in charge of the dwelling unit shall be solely responsible for the installation and maintenance of the smoke detectors and for battery replacement as required. 
2.  The tenant shall be responsible for informing the owner in writing of any smoke detector malfunction, including the need for a new battery. 
3.  The owner or person in charge of the dwelling unit shall check the battery at the beginning of a new lease and shall replace the battery at least annually as needed. 
4.  The owner or person in charge of the dwelling unit shall furnish to the tenant at the beginning of a new lease written notice of the responsibilities of the tenant and the obligations of the owner regarding smoke detector maintenance. 
H.  Gas Ranges. When provided or used in any dwelling unit subject to the provisions of this chapter, gas ranges, ovens and oven/range combinations of any type shall be installed, maintained and used or operated in a safe and nonhazardous manner, pursuant to any applicable state or national codes and regulations. Whenever such an appliance is found or determined to be or certified by the Wisconsin Power and Light Co., as unsafe or hazardous, no person shall use, nor shall any person permit others to use the appliance until all appropriate repairs have been made and the appliance is certified as safe for its intended use. 
I.  Doors. Exterior entry/exit doors shall be of solid core construction and capable of affording security by the installation of locking devices. Bedrooms shall be equipped with doors for privacy. 
(Prior Code, § 15-4-10; Code 1998, § 15.08.100; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997; Ord. No. 367, 1999) 
Sec. 15.08.110. - Minimum standards for heating, ventilation, electrical service and lighting. 
    All habitable buildings shall comply with the following requirements for the heating, ventilation, electrical service and lighting. 
A.  Heating. Every dwelling shall have heating facilities which are capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms and bathrooms to a temperature of at least 67 degrees above zero Fahrenheit with an outside temperature of 15 degrees below zero Fahrenheit without forcing the heating facilities beyond safe capacity. All facilities shall be operated to maintain at least this minimum temperature during all occupied periods. 
B.  Ventilation. Every habitable room shall be provided with window and/or door areas openable to the outside equal to at least four percent of the floor area, except when mechanical ventilation is provided, in which case the system shall be designated and installed in accordance with accepted engineering practices. 
1.  Every bathroom and toilet compartment shall have at least one window openable to the outside or be equipped with a mechanical exhaust ventilation system to the outside or approved ductless device. 
2.  When flies or other pests are prevalent, all windows and/or doors openable directly to the outside as required by this section shall be effectively screened. 
3.  All openings to a building or under a mobile home, which might provide an entry for rodents, shall be effectively protected at all times so as to prevent their entry. 
C.  Electrical Service. Every habitable room shall contain at least two separate wall-type electrical convenience outlets or one such convenience outlet and one ceiling-type or wall-type electrical fixture; every water closet compartment, laundry room, furnace room and public hall shall contain at least one ceiling or wall-type electric fixture and every bathroom shall contain one wall convenience outlet and one wall or ceiling light fixture. Every such outlet and fixture shall be properly installed and shall be maintained in a good and safe working condition and shall be connected to the source of the electric power in a safe manner and of a type approved by the State Electrical Code. In every building accommodating two or more dwelling units using the same corridors and stairways, adequate lighting shall be provided in such corridors and stairways when needed. Such lighting shall be operated by any of the following means: 
1.  Light switches in corridors to be conveniently located; 
2.  Light switches for stairs shall be at least the equivalent of a three-way light switch system located at the top and bottom of all stairways; 
3.  Any automatic type of operation which will maintain adequate lighting at all times, either natural or artificial. 
D.  Natural Lighting. Every habitable room shall be provided with window areas equal to at least eight percent of the floor area. 
(Prior Code, § 15-4-11; Code 1998, § 15.08.110; Ord. No. 347(part), 1997) 
Sec. 15.08.120. - Requirements for maintenance. 
    All habitable buildings and accessory structures shall comply with the following requirements for maintenance: 
A.  Floors, Walls, Etc. Every floor, wall, ceiling, exterior door, foundation and roof shall be weathertight, capable of affording privacy, kept in good repair and in a clean condition. 
1.  All rainwater shall be so drained from the roof so as not to cause unreasonable dampness in any wall, ceiling, or floor of a habitable room, bathroom or toilet room. 
2.  Exterior surfaces shall be painted or suitably surfaced to prevent unreasonable deterioration of the structure. 
3.  All windows shall be maintained in good repair and in a weathertight condition. 
4.  All interior doors shall be maintained in good repair. 
B.  Plumbing Systems. Plumbing shall be maintained in a sanitary and functional condition. Leaking, cracked or broken fixtures shall be considered unsanitary. 
C.  Stairs and Porches. Every inside and outside stair, every porch, every guardrail and every appurtenance thereto shall be so constructed as to be safe to use and capable of supporting the load that formal use would cause to be placed thereon, shall be kept in sound condition, good repair, and in a clean condition. Such stairs and porches shall be kept free of refuse, stored materials, excess furniture and appliances. 
D.  Chimney and Smoke Pipes. Every chimney and smoke pipe shall be adequately supported, reasonably clean, and maintained in a good state of repair, and with the proper clearances to combustible building materials. 
E.  Vacant Dwelling Units to be Clean Before Being Let For Occupancy. No owner shall rent to any person for occupancy or allow any other person to occupy any dwelling unit unless it is safe and clean and complies with all rules and regulations. 
F.  Discontinuance of Service. No owner, occupant or operator shall cause any required service, facility, equipment or utility to be removed from, shut off from, or discontinued for any occupied dwelling, except for such temporary interruption as may be necessary while actual repairs or alterations are in progress, or during a temporary emergency. 
G.  Cleanliness. Every dwelling unit shall be kept free of any accumulation of rubbish, trash, debris or other matter if the same tends to create a health and/or fire hazard.
